{{advert|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Leila Janah | image = Leila Janah (15499868092).jpg | image_size = | birth_date = {{b-da|October 9, 1982}} | birth_place = [[Lewiston, New York|Lewiston]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | occupation = Founder and [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of Sama and LXMI | known_for = | website = https://www.samasource.org/team | caption = Leila Janah in 2014 }}
'''Leila Janah''' is the Founder and [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of [[Samasource]] and [[LXMI]], two companies that share a common social mission to end global poverty by giving work to people in need. She is also the author of ''Give Work: Reversing Poverty One Job at a Time''<ref name=":4" /> and co-author of ''America's Moment: Creating Opportunity in the Connected Age'', a book by Rework America: A Markle Initiative.
==Early life== Janah was born on October 9, 1982 in [[Lewiston, New York]], near Niagara Falls,<ref>[http://www.crunchbase.com/person/leila-chirayath-janah Leila Janah's Crunchbase Profile]</ref> and grew up in [[San Pedro, Los Angeles]], California. She is the daughter of Indian immigrants, who came to the United States with nothing. Janah describes her childhood as being difficult, often due to a lack of financial security.<ref name=":0" /> As a teenager, Janah worked many jobs, including babysitting and tutoring.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.realsimple.com/work-life/life-strategies/job-career/leila-janah-samasource|title=How 1 Woman Changed 30,000 Lives|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> She attended the [[California Academy of Mathematics and Science]]. She won a scholarship at 17 through [[AFS Intercultural Programs|American Field Services]], and convinced them to let her spend it teaching in Ghana<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://twit.tv/shows/triangulation/episodes/316?autostart=false|title=Triangulation 316 Leila Janah: Give Work {{!}} TWiT.TV|website=TWiT.tv|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> where she spent 6 months during her senior year of high school.<ref name="stratford">http://www.stratford.edu/tech_talk_shows/shows/2011-03-01</ref> In Ghana, Janah taught English to young students in the village of Akuapem, many of whom were blind.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Making-a-difference/2014/1023/Leila-Janah-helps-people-in-the-developing-world-find-work-near-home|title=Leila Janah Helps People in the Developing World Find Work Near Home|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Janah has cited this early experience as sparking her passion for working in Africa, and she continued to visit the continent during her time in college.<ref name=":0" />
Janah attended [[Harvard University]], graduating in 2005 with a degree in African Development Studies.<ref>http://www.linkedin.com/in/leilajanah</ref> While at Harvard, Janah conducted fieldwork in [[Mozambique]], [[Senegal]] and [[Rwanda]] and consulted to and authored papers for the [[World Bank]]'s Development Research Group and [[Ashoka: Innovators for the Public|Ashoka]] on social and economic rights.<ref name=":1" />
==Career==
Upon graduation, Janah worked as a management consultant with [[Katzenbach Partners]] , focusing on healthcare, mobile and outsourcing companies. One of Janah's first assignments with Katzenbach Partners was managing a call center in [[Mumbai]]. At the call center Janah met a young man who traveled each day by rickshaw from [[Dharavi]], one of the largest slums in South Asia, to work at the center. Janah has cited this experience as sparking the inspiration for [[Samasource]], the non-profit she founded in 2008.<ref name=":1" />
Janah left Katzenbach Partners in 2007 to become a visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] with the Program on Global Justice, founded by law professor Joshua Cohen. That year, she co-founded Incentives for Global Health with [[Thomas Pogge]], Leitner Professor of Philosophy and International Affairs at [[Yale University|Yale]], and Aidan Hollis, a Professor of Economics at the [[University of Calgary]], which established a blueprint for incentivizing the development of new drugs for neglected diseases.<ref>http://www.samasource.org/about/team</ref>
===Samasource===
In 2008, Janah launched [[Samasource]] (then called Market for Change), an idea that was inspired by her time spent in Africa and her experience managing a call center in Mumbai.<ref name=":1" /> Samasource is a not-for-profit business with the mission to reduce global poverty by giving dignified online work to people living in poverty. Samasource uses an internet based model called [[microwork]] to break down large digital projects into smaller, easily trainable tasks for workers to complete at delivery centers. Samasource offers five services, including [[machine learning]], data verification and image annotation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.samasource.org/services|title=Samasource {{!}} Data Project Management {{!}} Data Solution for Businesses|website=Samasource {{!}} Data Project Management {{!}} Data Solution for Businesses|access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref> As of August, 2016, Samasource reports that it has impacted 32,265 people, which includes both direct Samasource workers and their dependents.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.samasource.org/impact|title=Samasource {{!}} Data Project Management {{!}} Data Solution for Businesses|website=Samasource {{!}} Data Project Management {{!}} Data Solution for Businesses|access-date=2016-08-28}}</ref> Samasource also reports that their workers increase their income by 3.7x over the course of four years.<ref name=":2" />
Janah got the capital to start Samasource from winning $14,000 in a business-plan competition at Stanford.<ref name=":0" /> She raised an additional $30,000 in a European business plan competition.<ref name=":0" /> In 2009, Samasource was selected to participate in fbFund, a $10m seed fund to support developers and entrepreneurs.<ref name=":1" /> Janah got her first contract for Samasource with a company called [[Benetech]], a non-profit social enterprise that provides technology solutions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sussman|first=Anna Louie|title=WOMAN OF THE WEEK: LEILA JANAH|url=http://womenintheworld.org/index.php/stories/entry/woman-of-the-week-leila-janah1|publisher=[[Women in the World Foundation]]|accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> Samasource has been named one of [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company's]] "Most Innovative Companies"<sup>[[Samasource#cite note-5|[5]]]</sup> and counts [[Walmart]], [[Google]] and [[eBay]] among its clients.
===Samaschool===
In 2013, Janah founded [[Samaschool]] (previously SamaUSA), a program that moves people out of poverty by providing digital skills training and a connection to internet-based jobs that pay a living wage<ref name=":4" />. Samaschool runs in-person programs in Arkansas, California, New York and Kenya, and also provides online classes that are available internationally. Samaschool courses train students in digital literary, workforce readiness and portfolio building.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.samaschool.org/trainings|title=Samaschool|website=Samaschool|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref>
Samaschool started with a pilot program in the [[Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco|Bayview-Hunters Point]] neighborhood in [[San Francisco]]. The model originally focused on training students to perform digital work competitively, to prepare them for success on online work sites like [[oDesk]] and [[Elance]]. The program was first introduced in a 2011 TechCrunch article<sup>[[Samasource#cite note-12|[12]]]</sup> which attracted controversy for its assertion that Americans could compete with African and Asian workers who can afford to take assignments that pay lower fees. Samaschool has since shifted its focus to teach students the skills necessary to gain work in the [[Temporary work|gig economy]]. Samaschool is funded in part by the [[Robin Hood Foundation|Robinhood Foundation]].
===Samahope===
Janah founded Samahope in 2012, the first crowdfunding platform that directly funded doctors who provide life-changing medical treatments for women and children in poor communities. Samahope enabled anyone anywhere to directly fund doctors' life-changing medical treatments for women and children in need. Samahope was built on the belief that transparent funding mechanisms could help close the global surgery gap and ensure that all people have access to medical treatments<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/leilajanah|title=Leila Janah|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Samahope combined with Johnson & Johnson's new global health platform, CaringCrowd, at the close of December 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-we-merged-samahope-case-nonprofit-ma-leila-janah?trk=mp-reader-card|title=Why We Merged: Samahope and the Case for Nonprofit M&A|date=2016-04-07|access-date=2016-08-19}}</ref> Janah spoke about the decision to merge with Caring Crowd in a [[LinkedIn]] post, citing efficiency and branding as the two biggest factors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-we-merged-samahope-case-nonprofit-ma-leila-janah|title=Why We Merged: Samahope and the Case for Nonprofit M&A|date=2016-04-07|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
===LXMI=== In 2015, Janah co-founded LXMI, a for profit luxury skin care brand.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-does-your-skincare-regimen-have-do-ending-leila-janah|title=Can your skincare routine help end poverty?|last=Janah|first=Leila|date=October 9, 2015|website=LinkedIn|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Built on the idea of beauty in action™, LXMI employs marginalized women in the rural Nile Valley communities<ref name=":4" /> to harvest LXMI ingredients and reports that their producers earn 3x the average local wages.<ref>http://lxmi.com/</ref> LXMI is named after the [[Lakshmi|Hindu goddess of beauty and prosperity]].<ref name=":3" />
LXMI was incubated at Samasource. Janah and Samasource are members of an LLC which owns LXMI, along with LXMI employees and investors. Currently, the jointly owned LLC owns 36% of LXMI, with Janah owning 24% and Samasource owning 12%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/e4cc5f_ac87fe6674474dac825c44ede5c38170.pdf|title=Samasource Independent Auditors' Report and Consolidated Financial Statements|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The LLC was set up for LXMI in order for Janah to donate the 1/3 of her shares back to Samasource in a way that would give Samasource oversight in the company. If LXMI pays a dividend or is acquired, Samasource would stand to benefit. [[Jones Day]] advised on the arrangement and referenced experience with other similar structures.
==Awards and honors== Janah is a Young Global Leader of the World Economic Forum, a Director of CARE USA, a 2012 TechFellow, recipient of the inaugural Club de Madrid Young Leadership Award, and the youngest person to win a [[Heinz Award]] in 2014 when she received the 19th Annual [[Heinz Awards|Heinz Award]] in Technology, the Economy and Employment.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Heinz Awards: Leila Janah|url=http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/leila-janah|website=The Heinz Awards|publisher=The Heinz Awards|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref> She also received the Secretary’s Innovation Award for the Empowerment of Women and Girls from Hillary Clinton in 2012, and is a former Visiting Scholar at the [[Stanford University]] Program on Global Justice<ref>[http://www.samasource.org/about/team#leila Samasource website]</ref> and [[Australian National University]]’s Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics. She is a recipient of the Rainer Arnhold and [[TED (conference)|TEDIndia]] Fellowships, and serves on the San Francisco board of [[TechSoup Global]] and the Social Enterprise Institute.<ref name="stratford"/>
Janah was included as one of [[Elle (magazine)|Elle Magazine's]] "Women in Tech"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/tech/a35725/women-in-tech-2016/|title=Meet Elle's 2016 Women in Tech|last=|first=|date=2016-05-13|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-19}}</ref> in 2016 and The New York Times T Magazine’s Five Visionary Tech Entrepreneurs Who Are Changing the World]” in 2015. She was also named a “Rising Star” on Forbes’ 30 Under 30 list in 2011, one of Fast Company’s “Most Creative People in Business” in 2012, and was profiled as one of Fortune’s “Most Promising Entrepreneurs” in 2013.

'''Luisa Battistati'''Her spelling in Hale's work is "Louisa", but this is a typical spelling of Anglophones when dealing with Italian names. was an Italian 19th-century woman who is recorded in American writer [[Sarah Josepha Hale]]’s ''Sketches of all distinguished women'' (1853) as a heroine of the insurrection against [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] rule that had taken place in [[Lombardy]] known as the [[Five Days of Milan]]. The revolt took place during the period 18–22 March 1848 and was successful in expelling the Austrian garrison, commanded by [[Josef Radetzky]], from the city. Radetzky would re-enter Milan on 6 August of that year, however, and Austria remained in control of the city until 1859. Hale wrote:
A native of [[Stradella, Lombardy|Stradella]], [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Sardinia]], and a [[mantua-maker]] at [[Milan]], [Luisa Battistati] displayed remarkable courage during the five days of the Revolution at Milan, in 1848. On Sunday, March 10th, she disarmed a cavalry soldier, though he carried a [[carbine]]. She placed herself at the head of the Poppietti bridge, and steadily continued there, fighting against the enemy during the 20th, 21st, and 22d days [of March],i.e. the final three days of the rebellion. heading a valiant band of young men, and killing a [[Croat]]e {{sic}} at every shot. She defended the large establishment at Vettabia,Probably this refers to the district of the Vettabbia canal, to the south of the city. which contained 580 persons, being the edifice in which the widows and their children, and other females took refuge when [[Frederick I Barbarossa|Barbaressa]] {{sic}} stormed Milan. This young woman was, in 1850, married, and doing duty in the civic guard.
Her entry in [[Henry Gardiner Adams]]’s ''A Cyclopaedia of Female Biography'' (1857) is identical down to the spelling,The Emperor Barbarossa again appears as ‘Barbaressa’. save for the statement that ‘[t]o this woman must be given a place in history, beside the [[Agustina de Aragón|heroine of Saragossa]], and other examples of female intrepidity’, while the description of Battistati in [[Ellen Creathorne Clayton]]’s ''Female Warriors : Memorials of Female Valour and Heroism, from the Mythological Ages to the Present Era'' (1879) is a paraphrase of Hale’s text.Not only does it read like a paraphrase, with no additional information added, but the bibliography to ''Female Warriors'' makes specific mention of Hale’s work: see [https://archive.org/stream/femalewarriorsme01clayiala#page/xiv/ vol. 1, p. xv]. She also appears in [[Jessica Amanda Salmonson]]’s ''The Encyclopedia of Amazons'' (1991). ==Notes== {{reflist|refs= "Sardinia" is for [[Kingdom of Sardinia]], then including what are now [[Piedmont]], [[Liguria]] and [[Sardinia]]. There were a number of places in the Kingdom of Sardinia called Stradella, including Cascina Stradella (pop. 24 in 2001) near [[Refrancore]] in the [[Province of Asti]] and a village (pop. 50) near [[Gambolò]] in the [[Lomellina]] to the south of [[Vigevano]]. But the [[Stradella, Lombardy|Stradella]] (pop. c. 10,000) in the [[Oltrepò Pavese]] seems the most likely. (Population figures from the 2001 census: [http://dawinci.istat.it/daWinci/jsp/MD/dawinciMD.jsp?a1=m0GG0c0I0&a2=mG0Y8048f8&n=1UH90T09OG0&v=1UH07B07R750000 Province of Asti] and [http://dawinci.istat.it/daWinci/jsp/MD/dawinciMD.jsp?a1=m0GG0c0I0&a2=mG0Y8048f8&n=1UH90T09OG0&v=1UH07B07RK50000 Province of Pavia]) [[Frederick I Barbarossa]], Holy Roman Emperor, destroyed Milan in 1162. }} ==References== * {{cite book | title=A Cyclopaedia of Female Biography | editor-first=Henry Gardiner |editor-last=Adams | publisher=Groombridge | year=1857 |place=London| page=94 |url=https://archive.org/details/acyclopaediafem01adamgoog}} * {{cite book|title=Female Warriors : Memorials of Female Valour and Heroism, from the Mythological Ages to the Present Era|first=Ellen Creathorne|last=Clayton|volume=2|place=London|publisher=Tinsley Brothers|year=1879|page=112 |url=https://archive.org/stream/femalewarriorsme02clayuoft#page/112}} * {{cite book|title=Woman's record; or, Sketches of all distinguished women, from "the beginning" till A.D. 1850|first=Sarah Josepha|last=Hale|place=New York|publisher=Harper and Brothers|year=1853|page=578|url=https://archive.org/stream/womansrecordorsk00hale#page/578}} * {{cite book | title=The Encyclopedia of Amazons | last=Salmonson|first=Jessica Amanda | publisher=Paragon House | year=1991 | pages=29|isbn=1-55778-420-5 }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battistati, Luisa}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:People from the Province of Pavia]] [[Category:History of Milan]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:Women in 19th-century warfare]] [[Category:Women in European warfare]] [[Category:19th-century Italian people]] [[Category:19th-century Italian women]]

{{Autism rights movement|people}}
'''Lydia Brown''' (born 1993) is an [[Asian American]] autistic disability rights activist, writer, and public speaker who was honored by the [[White House]] in 2013.<ref>Brown, Lydia. [https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2013/08/15/keeping-promise-ada-unequal-justice-disabled-victims-murder "Keeping the Promise of the ADA: Unequal Justice for Disabled Victims of Murder"], ''[[White House]]'', Washington, D.C., 15 August 2013.</ref> Brown is currently the chairperson of the [[Massachusetts Developmental Disabilities Council]].<ref>Massachusetts Developmental Disabilities Council, [https://www.scribd.com/doc/289948266/Press-Release-Lydia-Brown-MDDC "Massachusetts Developmental Disabilities Council Welcomes Lydia Brown as New Chairperson: Brown is Youngest Developmental Disabilities Council Chairperson in Country"], October 2015.</ref>
==Student activism== While an undergraduate student at [[Georgetown University]] from 2011 until graduating in 2015, Brown was also a student organizer and advocate for disabled students on campus.<ref>Quallen, Matthew. [http://www.thehoya.com/disabled-students-struggle-continues/ "For Disabled Students, The Struggle Continues"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 26 February 2015.</ref> Brown served as the first-ever Undersecretary of Disability Affairs for the [[Georgetown University Student Association]],<ref>Andrews, Avital. [https://psmag.com/social-justice/the-30-top-thinkers-under-30-the-self-described-queer-east-asian-disabled-person-devoted-to-defending-anyone-on-the-margins "The 30 Top Thinkers Under 30: The Self-Described Queer, East Asian Disabled Person Devoted to Defending Anyone on the Margins"], ''[[Pacific Standard]]'', 4 April 2015.</ref> wrote and disseminated a citywide guide to resources for students with disabilities,<ref>Welch, Caroline. [http://www.thehoya.com/gusa-tackles-accessibility/ "GUSA Tackles Accessibility"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 6 September 2013.</ref> designed a proposal for a Disability Cultural Center on campus,<ref>Rouge, Dominique. [http://georgetownvoice.com/2015/03/05/browns-proposal-for-the-establishment-of-a-disability-cultural-center-gains-momentum/ "Brown’s proposal for establishment of Disability Cultural Center gains momentum"], ''[[The Georgetown Voice]]'', 5 March 2015.</ref> surveyed student government candidates on disability issues,<ref>Henry, Lacey. [http://www.thehoya.com/disability-survey-reveals-support-from-gusa-candidates/ "Disability Survey Reveals Support From GUSA Candidates"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 24 February 2013.</ref><ref>Gregory, Matt. [http://www.thehoya.com/candidates-surveyed-on-disability-for-second-year/ "Candidates Surveyed on Disability for Second Year"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 27 February 2014.</ref> organized a [[Twitter]] chat by Georgetown students with disabilities,<ref>Monyak, Suzanne. [http://www.thehoya.com/strong-words-from-gus-disabled/ "Strong Words From GU’s Disabled"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 14 January 2014.</ref> and hosted and organized a Lecture & Performance Series on Disability Justice that featured talks with disability activists, scholars, and cultural workers including [[Karen Nakamura]], [[Margaret Price]], [[Leroy F. Moore Jr.]], [[Kassiane Asasumasu]], [[Stephanie Kerschbaum]], and [[Shain Neumeier|Shain M. Neumeier]].<ref>[http://www.disabilityjusticegu.com/events/disability-justice-series/ "Lecture & Performance Series on Disability Justice"], ''Disability Justice for Georgetown University'', 2015.</ref><ref>Allen, Charlotte. [http://www.thehoya.com/speaker-discusses-incarceration-of-disabled-people/ "Speaker Discusses Incarceration of Disabled People"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 11 November 2014.</ref><ref>Wallender, Andrew. [http://www.thehoya.com/panel-talks-disability-rights/ "Panel Talks Disability Rights"], ''[[The Hoya]]'', 31 October 2014.</ref>
==Career== Since graduating from Georgetown, Brown is now a Public Interest Law Scholar at [[Northeastern University School of Law]].<ref>[http://www.northeastern.edu/law/pdfs/financial-aid/pils-bios2016.pdf "Celebrating the Public Interest Law Scholars Program: Recipient Biographies for the Classes of 2003-2018"], ''[[Northeastern University School of Law]]'', January 2016, page 19.</ref> In Massachusetts, Brown first wrote and introduced legislation in 2010 on autism and developmental disabilities training for law enforcement, including corrections officers, and has continued to lobby for passage of that bill.<ref>General Court of Massachusetts, [http://www.mass.gov/legis/journal/hj062310.pdf "Journal of the House"], 23 June 2010, page 1498.</ref><ref>Segelbaum, Dani. [http://www.milforddailynews.com/article/20160209/NEWS/160205991 "Student pushes bill on autism training"], ''[[Milford Daily News]]'', 9 February 2016.</ref>
Brown worked as a policy analyst for the [[Autistic Self Advocacy Network]], a national disability rights organization led by and for autistic people until 2015,<ref>Autistic Self Advocacy Network, [http://autisticadvocacy.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/ASAN-2015-Annual-Report.pdf "2015 Annual Report"].</ref> and co-founded the [[Washington Metro Disabled Students Collective]].<ref>Washington Metro Disabled Students Collective, [https://disabledstudentsdc.org/leadership/ "Leadership"].</ref> Brown is also a former Patricia Morrissey Disability Policy Fellow at the [[Institute for Educational Leadership]].<ref>Institute for Educational Leadership, [http://ramp.iel.org/node/183 "IEL Celebrates White House Champions of Change"], 2013.</ref>
In 2011, Brown wrote a petition demanding school district-wide policy changes in [[Mercer County, Kentucky]] after viewing local news coverage of an incident in which Christopher Baker, a nine year old autistic student, was punished by being placed inside a large bag.<ref>Schreiner, Bruce. [http://archive.boston.com/news/education/k_12/articles/2011/12/22/school_accused_of_putting_autistic_student_in_bag/ "School accused of putting autistic student in bag"], ''[[Associated Press]]'', ''[[Boston Globe]]'', 22 December 2011.</ref> The petition gained over 200,000 signatures<ref>Brown, Lydia. "Petitioning Special Education, Mercer County Board of Education Emma Jean Tamme and 14 others: End abuse of Autistic students in Mercer County, Kentucky", ''[[Change.org]]'', December 2011.</ref> and news coverage by the [[Associated Press]]<ref>Schreiner, Bruce. [http://www.kentucky.com/site-services/newsletters/morning-newsletter/article44148390.html "Mom wants changes before she'll let autistic son return to Mercer school"], ''[[Associated Press]]'', 4 January 2012.</ref> and ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref>McVeigh, Karen. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/27/autistic-boy-duffel-bag-kentucky "Mother condemns Kentucky school for putting autistic son in duffel bag"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 27 December 2011.</ref>
In 2013, Brown co-organized a protest outside the [[Food and Drug Administration]] White Oak Campus in [[Maryland]] against the [[Judge Rotenberg Educational Center|Judge Rotenberg Center]], which is known for its use of painful [[aversives]] as a form of [[behavioral modification]] on people with [[developmental disabilities]], including many [[autistic]] people.<ref>[http://media-dis-n-dat.blogspot.com/2013/01/fda-meets-on-school-electric-shock.html "FDA meets on school electric shock device used on disabled students, warns of violations"], 11 January 2013.</ref> Later, in 2014, Brown testified against the Judge Rotenberg Center's use of electric shock aversives at a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel hearing.<ref>[[Food and Drug Administration]]. [http://www.fda.gov/downloads/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/MedicalDevices/MedicalDevicesAdvisoryCommittee/NeurologicalDevicesPanel/UCM398417.pdf "Transcript of Open Public Hearing of the Neurological Devices Panel, Medical Devices Advisory Committee, U.S. Food and Drug Administration"], 24 April 2014, pp.192-195.</ref> Prior to the hearing, Brown submitted lengthy written testimony on behalf of [[TASH (organization)|TASH New England]] arguing that electric shock aversive devices should be banned as an ineffective and dangerous form of treatment.<ref>Brown, Lydia. [https://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=FDA-2014-N-0238-0059 "Moral and Legal Bases for Banning Aversive Conditioning Devices Used for Contingent Electric Shock Lydia Brown Comment"], 18 April 2014.</ref> Brown maintains a living archive of documents and other resources related to the JRC on their website.<ref>Brown, Lydia. [http://www.autistichoya.net/judge-rotenberg-center/ "Judge Rotenberg Center Living Archive"], last updated 22 July 2016.</ref>
The [[Washington Peace Center]] selected Brown as the recipient of its 2014 Empowering the Future Youth Activist Award for their work with the [[Washington Metro Disabled Students Collective]] and the Autistic Self Advocacy Network.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://washingtonpeacecenter.net/pastawardees|title=Past Awardees|website=Washington Peace Center|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://washingtonpeacecenter.org/2014awardees|title=2014 Activist Awardees|website=Washington Peace Center|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref>
In 2015, Brown was named a Top Thinker Under 30 in the Social Sciences by ''[[Pacific Standard]]'' and included on [[Mic (media company)|Mic]]'s inaugural list of "the next generation of impactful leaders, cultural influencers, and breakthrough innovators."<ref>Andrews, Avital. [https://psmag.com/social-justice/the-30-top-thinkers-under-30-the-self-described-queer-east-asian-disabled-person-devoted-to-defending-anyone-on-the-margins "The 30 Top Thinkers Under 30: The Self-Described Queer, East Asian Disabled Person Devoted to Defending Anyone on the Margins"], ''[[Pacific Standard]]'', 4 April 2015.</ref><ref>[http://mic50.com/lydia-brown "Mic50: Lydia Brown"], ''[[Mic (media company)|Mic]]'', 2015.</ref> Brown has lectured on [[neurodiversity]]; connections between [[transgender|trans]], [[queer]], and [[disability]] experiences; [[racial justice]] and the [[disability rights movement]]; and [[intersectionality]] at numerous colleges and universities, including [[Yale University]],<ref>Giovanniello, Sarah. [http://www.broadrecognitionyale.com/2013/11/18/lydia-brown-looking-beyond-the-pathology-paradigm/ "Lydia Brown: Looking Beyond the Pathology Paradigm"], ''[[Broad Recognition]]'', 18 November 2013.</ref><ref>Lee, Jiwon. [http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2013/11/05/activist-challenges-social-perceptions-of-autism/ "Activist challenges social perceptions of autism"], ''[[Yale Daily News]]'', 5 November 2013.</ref> [[Bellevue College]],<ref>Yu, Fei. [http://www.thewatchdogonline.com/disability-awareness-month-2-19180 "Disability Awareness Month"], ''The Watchdog'', 30 September 2014.</ref> [[University of Virginia]],<ref>Parker, Elizabeth. [http://www.cavalierdaily.com/article/2015/04/queer-and-disabled-activist-lydia-brown-speaks-at-opengrounds "Queer and disabled activist Lydia Brown speaks at OpenGrounds: Georgetown University student discusses experiences with autism, self-advocacy"], ''[[The Cavalier Daily]]'', 8 April 2015.</ref> [[Grinnell College]],<ref>Coghlan, Nora. [http://www.thesandb.com/features/queer-culture-week-comes-out-to-grinnell.html "Queer Culture Week Comes Out to Grinnell"], ''[[Scarlet and Black]]'', 13 November 2014.</ref> [[College of William & Mary]],<ref>Cohen, Ariel. [http://flathatnews.com/2013/04/15/college-works-to-promote-neurodiversity/ "College Works To Promote Neurodiversity"], ''[[The Flat Hat]]'', 15 April 2013.</ref> and [[Vanderbilt University]] as part of the Inclusive Astronomy Conference.<ref>Tavares, Frank. [http://acvoice.com/2015/07/23/my-experiences-at-the-inclusive-astronomy-2015-conference-part-1/ "My Experiences at the Inclusive Astronomy 2015 Conference: Part 1"], ''AC Voice'', 23 July 2015.</ref> In 2015, Brown gave the keynote speech at the Students of Color Conference held in [[Yakima, Washington|Yakima]], Washington,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iexaminer.org/2015/07/column-students-of-color-conference-25-years-of-movement-building/|title=The International Examiner – Column: Students of Color Conference—25 years of movement building|last=Vo|first=Tony|website=www.iexaminer.org|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref> and in 2016, Brown gave the keynote speech at the Queer I Am Leadership Symposium held at [[South Puget Sound Community College]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://decspscc.weebly.com/queer-i-am.html|title=QueerIAm|website=Office of Diversity and Equity|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref>
Alongside [[E. Ashkenazy]] and [[Morénike Giwa-Onaiwu]], Brown is the lead editor of ''All the Weight of Our Dreams,'' an anthology of art and writing entirely by autistic people of color published by the [[Autistic Women & Nonbinary Network]] in June 2017.<ref>Brooks, Emily. [http://the-toast.net/2016/03/29/interview-with-steve-silberman/ An Interview with Steve Silberman, Author of ''NeuroTribes''], ''[[The Toast]]'', 29 March 2016.</ref><ref>Brown, Lydia X. Z. & The Autism Women's Network. [http://www.autismandrace.com All the Weight of Our Dreams: On Living Racialized Autism], 2016.</ref>

Jennifer Scuro (2017)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/995285877|title=Addressing ableism : philosophical questions via disability studies|last=Jennifer,|first=Scuro,|others=Reynolds, Joel Michael,, Havis, Devonya N.,, Brown, Lydia X. Z.,|isbn=9781498540742|location=Lanham, [Maryland]|oclc=995285877}}</ref> *"Ableist Shame and Disruptive Bodies: Survivorship at the Intersection of Queer, Trans, and Disabled Existence", ''Religion, Disability, and Interpersonal Violence''. ed. Andy J. Johnson, J. Ruth Nelson, & Emily M. Lund (2017)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/995767208|title=Religion, Disability, and Interpersonal Violence|date=2017|publisher=Springer Verlag|others=Johnson, Andy, Nelson, Ruth, Lund, Emily|isbn=9783319569000|oclc=995767208}}</ref> *''All the Weight of Our Dreams: On Living Racialized Autism''. ed. Ashkenazy, & Morénike Giwa Onaiwu (2017)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/991619149|title=All the weight of our dreams : on living racialized autism|others=Brown, Lydia X. Z.,, Ashkenazy, E.,, Onaiwu, Morénike Giwa,, Autistic Self Advocacy Network,|isbn=9780997504507|location=Lincoln, Nebraska|oclc=991619149}}</ref> *"Autism Isn't Speaking: Autistic Subversion in Media & Public Policy", ''Barriers and Belonging: Personal Narratives of Disability''. ed. Michelle Jarman, Leila Monaghan, & Alison Quaggin Harkin (2017)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/969434384|title=Barriers and belonging : personal narratives of disability|others=Jarman, Michelle, 1966-, Monaghan, Leila Frances, 1960-, Harkin, Alison Quaggin, 1958-|isbn=9781439913888|location=Philadelphia|oclc=969434384}}</ref> *"'You Don’t Feel Like A Freak Anymore': Representing Disability, Madness, and Trauma in Litchfield Penitentiary", ''Feminist Perspectives on Orange Is The New Black: Thirteen Critical Essays.'' ed. use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }}
'''Mahabir Pun''' is a Nepalese teacher,<ref name="Teacher">{{cite web| url=http://himanchal.org/mahabir-pun/ |title=Mahabir Taught 5 years in Himanchal Higher Secondary School |accessdate=2016-09-06| date=2016-09-06 |work=Himanchal Education Foundation}}</ref> [[social entrepreneur]] <ref name="social enterpreneur">{{cite web| url=http://storycycle.com/stories/story/29 |title=Villages Should be self dependent |accessdate=2016-09-06| date=2014-07-28 |work=Story Cycle}}</ref> and an activist <ref name="Kantipur">{{cite web| url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-08-01/tired-of-seeking-funds-pun-offers-own-land-to-run-innovation-hub.html |title=Mahabir donates his own land to make Innovation Center possible |accessdate=2016-09-06| date=2016-08-01 |work=Kantipur Network}}</ref> known for his extensive work in applying [[wireless technologies]] to develop remote areas of the [[Himalayas]], also known as the [[Nepal Wireless Networking Project]].<ref name="bbc1">{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/1606580.stm |title=Village in the clouds embraces computers |accessdate=2010-11-01| date=2001-10-22 |work=BBC News}}</ref> <ref name="bbc2">{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7708558.stm |title=Internet dream becomes a reality |accessdate=2010-11-01 |date=2008-11-05 |work=BBC News}}</ref> He is a widely known figure in Nepal, and his work has been recognized by the Ashoka Foundation, the Ramon Magsaysay Foundation, University of Nebraska, and [[Global Ideas Bank]].<ref name=Ashoka /><ref name=Nebraska /><ref name=Magsaysay /><ref name=globalideasbank /> He is a humanitarian whose work is inspiring many youths to return their own country and serve it for its development. Mahabir Pun is a person with phenomenal qualities, he is always ready to eradicate different problems inside the country.
== Early life and education==
Born and raised in Nangi, a remote village in the mountainous district [[Myagdi District]] of western Nepal, Pun spent his childhood grazing cattle and sheep and attending a village school without paper, pencils, textbooks or qualified teachers. Traditionally, the local people had no education, and most men joined the British [[Gurkha]] army. Pun's life changed dramatically when his father, a retired Gurkha, took the remarkable step of moving the family to the southern plain of Nepal and investing their entire savings in his son's education. After finishing high school, Pun worked as a teacher for about 12 years in four schools, while supporting his brothers' and sisters' education. In 1989, after numerous applications to UK and US universities, he succeeded in gaining a partial scholarship to the [[University of Nebraska at Kearney]], from which he graduated in 1996 with a bachelor's degree in Science Education. After graduation, he returned to his native village, twenty-four years after having left there as a child. It was in Nangi that he recognised the critical need for sustainable education, and began to formulate his goal of creating a high school to serve as a model for local educational and economic development. Pun founded the Himanchal High School with a special focus on computer education and other programmes with income-generating capacity. He then returned to the University of Nebraska for a master's degree in Educational Administration, which he completed in 2001.<ref name=Ashoka>{{cite web |url=http://www.ashoka.org/fellow/2754 |title=Mahabir Pun - Ashoka.org |accessdate=2010-11-01 |year=2002 |publisher=[[Ashoka Foundation]] }}</ref><ref name=Himanchal>{{cite web |url=http://www.himanchal.org/mahabir-pun/ |title=Mahabir Pun |accessdate=2010-11-01 |year=2008 |publisher=Himanchal Educational Foundation }}</ref>
==Educational and economic development== [[File:TeleNepal.jpg|thumb|Mahabir Pun hand-making a satellite dish in [[Nepal]]]]
While in the United States of America, Pun had recognised that information technology had the potential to transform the education system and the economy of his village, and he had taken courses to acquire the skills needed to assemble, refurbish and use computers. On his return to Nepal, he successfully campaigned for the donation of used computers from Japan, Malaysia, Australia, [[Singapore]], and the USA, and powered them with two small [[Micro hydro|hydro generators]] (donated by Singaporean climbers on their way to [[Mount Everest]]) installed in a nearby stream. Pun began teaching computer classes to students and fellow teachers, but it proved impossible to establish a telephone connection to the nearest city, [[Pokhara]], and the Internet. Pun e-mailed the [[BBC]], asking for ideas. The BBC publicised his dilemma, and soon volunteers from Europe and the USA responded. In 2001, donors and volunteers helped him to rig a wireless connection between Nangi and the neighbouring village of Ramche, using small handmade TV dish antennae mounted in trees. Small grants soon led to the construction of improvised mountaintop relay stations and a link to [[Pokhara]]. By 2003, Nangi had a wireless connection to the Internet. Later, Pun brought in more used computers donated from abroad, distributed them to other schools in other villages, and began work to develop a wireless distance-learning project supported by income-generating ventures.
Pun's work on distance learning and online educational services constitutes the first attempt in Nepal to address the scarcity of qualified teachers through technology. He took steps to ensure the success and growth of his projects, by arranging for other teachers to attend a computer training course in Pokhara, starting economic projects to fund students' expenses and teachers' salaries, and by attracting hundreds of international volunteers with wide-ranging skills. He has since built a new cultural centre, and has developed communication links for yak farmers, as well as new ventures to hc international trekking and tour groups. He has, therefore, succeeded not just in creating a self-sustaining educational system, but also a range of new economic and social enterprises to support remote communities.<ref name=Ashoka /><ref name=Himanchal /><ref name=ghurkas>{{cite web |url=http://www.gurkhas.com/showarticle.aspx?id=486 |title=Welcome to Dr Mahabir Pun in UK on Thursday 6 Nov 2008 |accessdate=2010-11-01 |date=2008-11-06 |publisher=Ghurkas.com }}</ref>
==National Innovation Center ( राष्ट्रिय आविष्कार केन्द्र् )== Mahabir Pun led the initiative to register a Nonprofit named "Rashtriya Abiskar Kendra" in 2012, widely termed as National Innovation Center in English. Primary objective to establish the Innovation center according to Mahabir is to foster research and developments for the economic development of the country.Mahabir worked with the government for funding of the project which did not happen and since July 2016,<ref name=NIC1>{{cite web |url=http://nepalitimes.com/article/nation/innovating-a-new-nepal,179 |title= National Innovation Center, Innovating New Nepal |accessdate=2016-09-06 |date=2016-08-10 |publisher=My Republica }}</ref> Mahabir is running a crowd funding campaign to fund National Innovation efforts. National Innovation Center crowd funding campaign plans to collect build a 10MW hydropower station, which according to the initiative would sustainably fund it's running cost.<ref name=NIC2>{{cite web |url=http://www.nicnepal.org/concept-paper/ |title= NIC Nepal Concept Paper |accessdate=2016-09-06 |date=2016-08-31 |publisher=National Innovation Center }}</ref><ref name=NIC3>{{cite web |url=http://www.myrepublica.com/news/3546 |title= National Innovation Center to collect money from crowd-funding|accessdate=2016-09-06 |date=2016-08-31 |publisher=National Innovation Center }}</ref> Mahabir has got social attraction with his donation of land for the National Innovation Center.<ref name=Online1>{{cite web |url=http://english.onlinekhabar.com/2016/07/31/382846 |title= Dr Mahabir Pun Donates 28 Ropanies of Land to National Innovation Center |accessdate=2016-09-06 |date=2016-07-31 |publisher=Online Khabar }}</ref> The former prime minister of Nepal, [[Pushpa Kamal Dahal|Prachanda]] announced to hand NRS 15 millions to National Innovation Center.
==International recognition== In 2002, Pun was elected Ashoka Fellow by the Ashoka Foundation, the global association of leading social entrepreneurs. The Foundation noted Pun's contribution to overcoming the geographical isolation of many of the communities in which he works, with a new idea which could be replicated in other geographically isolated areas with few educational or economic opportunities.<ref name=Ashoka />
Mahabir Pun was inducted in Internet Hall of Fame as an inductee in 2014 - <ref name="Internet Hall of Fame">{{cite web |url=http://internethalloffame.org/inductees/mahabir-pun |title=Internet Hall of Fame Inductee |accessdate=2016-01-16 |date=2016-01-16 |publisher=[[Internet Hall of Fame by Internet Society]] }}</ref>
In 2004, Pun received the Overall Social Innovations Award from the [[Global Ideas Bank]], aka the [[Institute for Social Inventions]]. They said, "Using an inspired mix of solar power, tree-based relay systems, and wireless technology, the project is helping yak farmers stay in touch, families communicate and, with an expansion into distance learning, children to gain the education." <ref name=globalideasbank>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalideasbank.org/site/news/index.php?articleId=116 |title=Social Innovations Award-Winners 2004 |accessdate=2010-11-01 |date=2004-09-20 |publisher=[[Global Ideas Bank]] }}</ref>
In 2007, Pun was awarded the [[Magsaysay Award]], considered by some to be the [[Nobel Prize]] of [[Asia]], in recognition of "his innovative application of wireless computer technology in Nepal, bringing progress to remote mountain areas by connecting his village to the global village".<ref name=Magsaysay>{{cite web |url=http://www.rmaf.org.ph/Awardees/Citation/CitationPunMah.htm |title=The 2007 Ramon Magsaysay Award for Community Leadership |accessdate=2010-11-01 |date=2007-08-31 |publisher=Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation }}</ref> Pun is one of four Nepalis to receive the Magsaysay Award, and the only one to receive the Magsaysay Award for Community Leadership.<ref name=magsaysaylist>{{cite web | url=http://www.rmaf.org.ph/Awardees/year.htm|title=The Raymond Magsaysay Awardees by Year|accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref>
Later in 2007, the University of Nebraska awarded Pun an [[honorary degree]] as [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] for his outstanding work for his country, Nepal.<ref name=Nebraska>{{cite web |url=http://www.unk.edu/news/index.php?id=35392 |title=Mahabir Pun's Commencement Address: Dec 2007 |accessdate=2010-11-01 |date=2007-12-21 |publisher=[[University of Nebraska]] }}</ref>
In 2014 Pun was awarded the [[Jonathan B. Postel Service Award]] by the [[Internet Society]].

{{short description|Roman god of war, and guardian of agriculture}} {{distinguish|text=the planet [[Mars]]}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox deity |type = Roman |name = Mars |image = File:0 Statue de Mars (Pyrrhus) - Musei Capitolini - MC0058 (2).JPG |caption =The Statue of Mars from the [[Forum of Nerva]], 2nd century AD, based on an [[Augustus|Augustan-era]] original that in turn used a [[Hellenistic art|Hellenistic Greek model]] of the 4th century BC. [[Capitoline Museums]] in Rome, Italy.<ref>Capitoline Museums. "[http://capitolini.info/scu00058/?lang=en Colossal statue of Mars Ultor also known as Pyrrhus – Inv. Scu 58.]" Capitolini.information. Accessed 8 October 2016.</ref> |god_of = ''Pater'' of the Roman people, Guardian of [[Roman army|soldiers]] and [[Roman agriculture|farmers]], God of [[god of war|War]], Destruction and [[Masculinity]] |abode = |symbol = [[Mars symbol|The spear of Mars ♂]] (Spear and shield iconography) |consort = [[Nerio]] and others like [[Rhea Silvia]], [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]], [[Bellona (goddess)|Bellona]] |parents = [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] and [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]] |siblings = [[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]], [[Minerva]], [[Hercules]], [[Bellona (goddess)|Bellona]], [[Apollo]], [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]], [[Dionysus|Bacchus]], etc. |children = [[Romulus and Remus]] |mount = |Etruscan_equivalent=possibly [[Maris (mythology)|Maris]] |Greek_equivalent = [[Ares]] }} In [[ancient Roman religion]] and [[Roman mythology|myth]], '''Mars''' ({{lang-la|Mārs}}, {{IPA-la|maːrs|}}) was the [[god of war]] and also an [[Roman agriculture|agricultural]] guardian, a combination characteristic of early [[ancient Rome|Rome]].<ref>[[Mary Beard (classicist)|Mary Beard]], J.A. North, and S.R.F. Price, ''Religions of Rome: A History'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998), pp. 47–48.</ref> He was second in importance only to [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] and he was the most prominent of the military gods in the [[Religion in the Roman military|religion of the Roman army]]. Most of his [[Roman festivals|festivals]] were held in March, the month named for him ([[Martius (month)|Latin ''Martius'']]), and in October, which began the season for military campaigning and ended the season for farming.
Under the [[Hellenization|influence of Greek culture]], Mars was [[interpretatio graeca|identified with]] the [[Greek mythology|Greek god]] [[Ares]],<ref name=Lar>''Larousse Desk Reference Encyclopedia'', [[The Book People]], Haydock, 1995, p. 215.</ref> whose [[myth]]s were reinterpreted in [[Latin literature|Roman literature]] and [[Roman art|art]] under the name of Mars. But the character and dignity of Mars differed in fundamental ways from that of his Greek counterpart, who is often treated with contempt and revulsion in [[Ancient Greek literature|Greek literature]].<ref>Kurt A. Raaflaub, ''War and Peace in the Ancient World'' (Blackwell, 2007), p. 15.</ref> Mars was a part of the [[Capitoline Triad|Archaic Triad]] along with Jupiter and [[Quirinus]], the latter of whom, as a guardian of the Roman people, had no Greek equivalent. Mars' altar in the [[Campus Martius]], the area of Rome that took its name from him, was supposed to have been dedicated by [[Numa Pompilius|Numa]], the peace-loving semi-legendary second [[Kings of Rome|king of Rome]]. Although the center of Mars' worship was originally located outside the sacred boundary of Rome ''([[pomerium]])'', [[Augustus]] made the god a renewed focus of [[Religion in ancient Rome|Roman religion]] by establishing the Temple of Mars Ultor in [[Forum of Augustus|his new forum]].<ref>Paul Rehak and John G. Younger, ''Imperium and Cosmos: Augustus and the Northern Campus Martius'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 2006), pp. 11–12.</ref>
Although Ares was viewed primarily as a destructive and destabilizing force, Mars represented military power as a way [[Pax Romana|to secure peace]], and was a father ''(pater)'' of the Roman people.<ref>[[Isidore of Seville]] calls Mars ''Romanae gentis auctorem'', the originator or founder of the Roman people as a ''[[gens]]'' (''Etymologiae'' 5.33.5).</ref> In the mythic [[genealogy]] and [[Founding of Rome|founding myths of Rome]], Mars was the father of [[Romulus and Remus]] with [[Rhea Silvia]]. His love affair with [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] symbolically reconciled the two different traditions of Rome's founding; Venus was the divine mother of the hero [[Aeneas]], celebrated as the [[Trojan War|Trojan refugee]] who "founded" Rome several generations before Romulus laid out the city walls.
The importance of Mars in establishing religious and cultural identity within the [[Roman Empire]] is indicated by the vast number of [[epigraphy|inscriptions]] identifying him with a local deity, particularly in the [[Roman province|Western provinces]].
Mars may ultimately be a reflex of the [[Proto-Indo-European religion|Proto-Indo-European]] god [[Perkwunos]], having originally a thunderer character.<ref>York, Michael. Romulus and Remus, Mars and Quirinus. Journal of Indo-European Studies 16:1 & 2 (Spring/Summer, 1988), 153–172.</ref> At least etymological [[Etruscan]] predecessors are present in [[Maris (mythology)|Maris]],<ref>Pallotino, pp. 29, 30; Hendrik Wagenvoort, "The Origin of the Ludi Saeculares," in Studies in Roman Literature, Culture and Religion (Brill, 1956), p. 219 et passim; John F. Hall III, "The Saeculum Novum of Augustus and its Etruscan Antecedents," Aufstieg und Niedergang der römischen Welt II.16.3 (1986), p. 2574.</ref> though this is not universally agreed upon.<ref> Larissa Bonfante, Etruscan Life and Afterlife: A Handbook of Etruscan Studies (Wayne State University Press, 1986), p. 226.</ref>
==Birth== {{Ancient Roman religion}} Like Ares who was the son of [[Zeus]] and [[Hera]],<ref>[[Hesiod]], ''Theogony'' p. 79 in the translation of Norman O. Brown (Bobbs-Merrill, 1953); 921 in the [[Loeb Classical Library]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=lnCXI9oFeroC&dq=Ares+intitle%3Atheogony+inauthor%3Ahesiod&q=%22she%2C+mingling+in+love%22+Ares#v=snippet&q=%22she%2C%20mingling%20in%20love%22%20Ares&f=false numbering]; ''[[Iliad]]'', 5.890–896.</ref> Mars is usually considered to be the son of [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] and [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]]. However, in a version of his birth given by [[Ovid]], he was the son of Juno alone. Jupiter had usurped the mother's function when he gave birth to [[Minerva]] directly from his forehead (or mind); to restore the balance, Juno sought the advice of the goddess [[Flora (mythology)|Flora]] on how to do the same. Flora obtained a magic flower (Latin ''flos'', plural ''flores'', a [[grammatical gender|masculine word]]) and tested it on a [[wikt:heifer|heifer]] who became fecund at once. She then plucked a flower ritually using her thumb, touched Juno's belly, and impregnated her. Juno withdrew to [[Thrace]] and the [[Sea of Marmara|shore of Marmara]] for the birth.<ref name=Mars-birth>[[Ovid]], ''[[Fasti (poem)|Fasti]]'' [https://archive.org/stream/ovidsfasti00oviduoft#page/276/mode/2up 5.229–260]</ref>
[[Ovid]] tells this story in the ''[[Fasti (Ovid)|Fasti]]'', his long-form poetic work on the [[Roman calendar]].<ref name=Mars-birth/> It may explain why the [[Matronalia]], a festival celebrated by married women in honor of Juno as a [[Lucina (goddess)|goddess of childbirth]], occurred on the first day of Mars' month, which is also marked on a [[Chronography of 354|calendar from late antiquity]] as the birthday of Mars. In the earliest Roman calendar, March was the first month, and the god would have been born with the new year.<ref>[[William Warde Fowler]], ''The Roman Festivals of the Period of the Republic'' (London, 1908), p. 35f., discusses this interpretation in order to question it.</ref> Ovid is the only source for the story. He may be presenting a literary myth of his own invention, or an otherwise unknown [[Ancient peoples of Italy|archaic Italic]] tradition; either way, in choosing to include the story, he emphasizes that Mars was connected to plant life and was not alienated from female nurture.<ref>Carole E. Newlands, ''Playing with Time: Ovid and the Fasti'' (Cornell University Press, 1995), pp. 105–106.</ref>
==Consort== The [[wikt:consort|consort]] of Mars was [[Nerio]] or Neriene, "Valor." She represents the vital force ''(vis)'', power ''(potentia)'' and majesty ''(maiestas)'' of Mars.<ref>[[Aulus Gellius]], ''Attic Nights'' 13.23. Gellius says the word ''Nerio'' or ''Nerienes'' is [[Sabine language|Sabine]] and is supposed to be the origin of the [[cognomen|name]] ''Nero'' as used by the [[Claudia (gens)|Claudian family]], who were [[Sabines|Sabine]] in origin. The Sabines themselves, Gellius says, thought the word was [[ancient Greek language|Greek]] in origin, from νεῦρα ''(neura)'', Latin ''nervi'', meaning the sinews and ligaments of the limbs.</ref> Her name was regarded as [[Sabine language|Sabine]] in origin and is equivalent to Latin ''[[virtus (virtue)|virtus]],'' "manly virtue" (from ''vir'', "man").<ref>[[Robert E.A. Palmer]], ''The Archaic Community of the Romans'' (Cambridge University Press, 1970, 2009), p. 167.</ref> In the early 3rd century BC, the comic playwright [[Plautus]] has a reference to Mars greeting Nerio, his wife.<ref>[[Plautus]], ''Truculentus'' 515.</ref> A source from [[late antiquity]] says that Mars and Neriene were celebrated together at a festival held on March 23.<ref>[[Johannes Lydus]], ''De mensibus'' 4.60 (42).</ref> In the later [[Roman Empire]], Neriene came to be identified with Minerva.<ref>[[Pomponius Porphyrion|Porphyrion]], ''Commentum in Horatium Flaccum'', on ''Epistula'' II.2.209.</ref>
Nerio probably originates as a divine [[personification]] of Mars' power, as such [[abstraction]]s in Latin are generally [[grammatical gender|feminine]]. Her name appears with that of Mars in an archaic prayer [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#invocatio|invoking]] a series of abstract qualities, each paired with the name of a deity. The influence of [[Greek mythology]] and its [[Anthropotheism|anthropomorphic gods]] may have caused Roman writers to treat these pairs as "marriages."<ref>[[William Warde Fowler]], ''The Religious Experience of the Roman People'' (London, 1922), p. 150–154; Roger D. Woodard, ''Indo-European Sacred Space: Vedic and Roman Cult'' (University of Illinois Press, 2006), pp. 113–114; Gary Forsythe, ''A Critical History of Early Rome: From Prehistory to the First Punic War'' (University of California Press, 2005), p. 145. The prayer is recorded in the passage on Nerio in Aulus Gellius.</ref><!--[[Augustine of Hippo|St. Augustine]] disapprovingly gives Mars and the war goddess [[Bellona (goddess)|Bellona]] as an example of a divine couple who were also sister and brother.<ref>[[Augustine]], ''De civitate Dei'' 6.10, citing Seneca; Fowler doubts the authority of the passage (''Religious Experience'', p. 166, note 16).</ref>-->
===Venus and Mars=== [[File:Mars and Venus MAN Napoli Inv9248.jpg|thumb|left|Wall painting (mid-1st century AD) from which the House of Venus and Mars at [[Pompeii]] takes its name]] The union of Venus and Mars held greater appeal for poets and philosophers, and the couple were a frequent subject of art. In Greek myth, the adultery of [[Ares]] and [[Aphrodite]] had been exposed to ridicule when her husband [[Hephaestus]] (whose Roman equivalent was [[Vulcanus|Vulcan]]) caught them in the act by means of a magical snare. Although not originally part of the Roman tradition, in 217 BC Venus and Mars were presented as a complementary pair in the ''[[lectisternium]]'', a public banquet at which images of [[Di Consentes|twelve major gods]] of the Roman state were presented on couches as if present and participating.<ref>Robert Schilling, "Venus," in ''Roman and European Mythologies'' (University of Chicago Press, 1992, from the French edition of 1981), p. 147.</ref>
Scenes of Venus and Mars in [[Roman art]] often ignore the adulterous implications of their union, and take pleasure in the good-looking couple attended by [[Cupid]] or multiple Loves ''(amores)''. Some scenes may imply marriage,<ref>John R. Clarke, ''The Houses of Roman Italy, 100 B.C.–A.D. 250: Ritual, Space, and Decoration'' (University of California Press, 1991), pp. 156–157</ref> and the relationship was romanticized in funerary or domestic art in which husbands and wives had themselves portrayed as the passionate divine couple.<ref>Laura Salah Nasrallah, ''Christian Responses to Roman Art and Architecture: The Second-Century Church amid the Spaces of Empire'' (Cambridge University Press, 2010), pp. 284–287.</ref>
The uniting of deities representing Love and War lent itself to [[allegory]], especially since the lovers were the parents of [[Concordia (mythology)|Concordia]].{{fact|date=September 2017}} The Renaissance philosopher [[Marsilio Ficino]] notes that "only Venus dominates Mars, and he never dominates her".<ref>Ficino, ''On Love'', speech 5, chapter 8, as summarized in the entry on "Mars," ''The Classical Tradition'' (Harvard University Press, 2010), p. 564.</ref> In ancient Roman and Renaissance art, Mars is often shown disarmed and relaxed, or even sleeping, but the extramarital nature of their affair can also suggest that this peace is impermanent.<ref>Entry on "Mars" in ''The Classical Tradition,'' p. 564.</ref>
==Essential nature== [[File:Campanian bowl with Mars and Venus.JPG|thumb|A relief depicting Mars and [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] on a [[black-slip]] bowl from [[Campania]], Italy, 250–150 BC, [[British Museum]]]] [[Virility]] as a kind of life force ''(vis)'' or virtue ''(virtus)'' is an essential characteristic of Mars.<ref>R.B. Onians, ''The Origins of European Thought about the Body, the Mind, the Soul, the World, Time and Fate'' (Cambridge University Press, 1951), pp. 470–471. Onians connects the name of Mars to the Latin ''mas, maris'', "male" (p. 178), as had Isidore of Seville, saying that the month of March ''(Martius)'' was named after Mars "because at that time all living things are stirred toward virility (''mas'', gen. ''maris'') and to the pleasures of sexual intercourse" ''(eo tempore cuncta animantia agantur ad marem et ad concumbendi voluptatem)'': ''Etymologies'' 5.33.5, translation by Stephen A. Barney, ''The Etymologies of Isidore of Seville'' (Cambridge University Press, 2006), p. 128. In antiquity, ''vis'' was thought to be related etymologically to ''vita'', "life." Varro (''De lingua latina'' 5.64, quoting [[Gaius Lucilius|Lucilius]]) notes that ''vis'' is ''vita'': "''vis'' drives us to do everything."</ref> As an agricultural guardian, he directs his energies toward creating conditions that allow crops to grow, which may include warding off hostile forces of nature.<ref>On the relation of Mars' warrior aspect to his agricultural functions with respect to Dumézil's [[Trifunctional hypothesis]], see Wouter W. Belier, ''Decayed Gods: Origin and Development of Georges Dumézil's 'idéologie tripartie' '' (Brill, 1991), pp. 88–91 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Hs3BpWur0_4C&pg=PA88&dq=%22Besides+the+obviously+warlike+aspects+of+Mars+there+are+also+features+which+have+an+agricultural+aspect%22&hl=en&ei=uU3wTNcEyeydB42G2OAK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Besides%20the%20obviously%20warlike%20aspects%20of%20Mars%20there%20are%20also%20features%20which%20have%20an%20agricultural%20aspect%22&f=false online.]</ref> As an embodiment of masculine aggression, he is the force that drives wars – but ideally, war that delivers a secure peace.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}}
The priesthood of the [[Arval Brethren|Arval Brothers]] called on Mars to drive off "rust" ''(lues)'', with its double meaning of [[Wheat leaf rust|wheat fungus]] and the [[rust|red oxides]] that affect metal, a threat to both iron farm implements and weaponry. In the [[Carmen Arvale|surviving text of their hymn]], the Arval Brothers invoked Mars as ''ferus'', "savage" or "feral" like a wild animal.<ref>Schilling, "Mars," in ''Roman and European Mythologies'', p. 135; Palmer, ''Archaic Community'', pp. 113–114.</ref>
Mars' potential for savagery is expressed in his obscure connections to the wild woodlands, and he may even have originated as a god of the wild, beyond the boundaries set by humans, and thus a force to be [[wikt:propitiate|propitiated]].<ref>Gary Forsythe, ''A Critical History of Early Rome'' (University of California Press, 2005), p. 127; Fowler, ''Religious Experience'', p. 134.</ref> In his [[De Agri Cultura|book on farming]], [[Cato the Elder|Cato]] invokes ''[[Mars (mythology)#Mars Silvanus|Mars Silvanus]]'' for a ritual to be carried out ''in silva'', in the woods, an uncultivated place that if not held within bounds can threaten to overtake the fields needed for crops.<ref>[[Cato the Elder|Cato]], ''On Agriculture'' 141. In pre-modern agricultural societies, encroaching woodland or wild growth was a real threat to the food supply, since clearing land for cultivation required intense manual labor with minimal tools and little or no large-scale machinery. Fowler says of Mars, "As he was not localised either on the farm or in the city, I prefer to think that he was originally conceived as a Power outside the boundary in each case, but for that very reason all the more to be propitiated by the settlers within it" (''Religious Experience'', p. 142).</ref> Mars' character as an agricultural god may derive solely from his role as a defender and protector,<ref>Schilling, "Mars," p. 135.</ref> or may be inseparable from his warrior nature,<ref>Beard ''et al.'', ''Religions of Rome: A History'', pp. 47–48.</ref> as the leaping of his armed priests the [[Salii]] was meant to quicken the growth of crops.<ref>Forsythe, ''A Critical History of Early Rome'', p. 127</ref>
It appears that Mars was originally a thunderer or storm deity, which explains some of his mixed traits in regards to fertility.<ref>York, Michael. Romulus and Remus, Mars and Quirinus. Journal of Indo-European Studies 16:1 & 2 (Spring/Summer, 1988), 153–172.</ref> This role was later taken in the Roman pantheon by several other gods, such as [[Summanus]] or [[Jupiter]].
==Sacred animals== [[File:Altar Mars Venus Massimo lupa.jpg|thumb|[[She-wolf (Roman mythology)|She-wolf]] and twins [[Romulus and Remus]] from an altar to Venus and Mars]] The wild animals most sacred to Mars were the woodpecker, the wolf, and the bear, which in the natural lore of the Romans were said always to inhabit the same foothills and woodlands.<ref>Plutarch, ''Roman Questions'' 21, citing [[Nigidius Figulus]].</ref>
[[Plutarch]] notes that the woodpecker ''(picus)'' is sacred to Mars because "it is a courageous and spirited bird and has a [[beak]] so strong that it can overturn oaks by pecking them until it has reached the inmost part of the tree."<ref>[[Plutarch]], ''Roman Questions'' 21; also named as sacred to Mars in his ''Life of Romulus''. Ovid (''Fasti'' 3.37) calls the woodpecker the bird of Mars.</ref> As the beak of the ''picus Martius'' contained the god's power to ward off harm, it was carried as a [[amulet|magic charm]] to prevent [[bee sting]]s and [[leech]] bites.<ref>[[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Natural History'' 29.29.</ref> The bird of Mars also guarded a woodland herb ''([[paeonia (plant)|paeonia]])'' used for treatment of the [[Human gastrointestinal tract|digestive]] or [[Female reproductive system (human)|female reproductive systems]]; those who sought to harvest it were advised to do so by night, lest the woodpecker jab out their eyes.<ref>Pliny, ''Natural History'' 27.60. Pliny names the herb as ''glycysīdē'' in Greek, Latin ''[[paeonia (plant)|paeonia]]'' (see [[Peony#Name|Peony: Name]]), also called ''pentorobos''.</ref> The ''picus Martius'' seems to have been a particular species, but authorities differ on which one: perhaps ''[[Picus viridis]]''<ref>A.H. Krappe, "Picus Who Is Also Zeus," ''Mnemosyne'' 9.4 (1941), p. 241.</ref> or ''[[Dryocopus martius]]''.<ref>[[William Geoffrey Arnott]], ''Birds in the ancient world from A to Z'' (Routledge, 2007), p. 63 [https://books.google.com/books?id=0NB4qqenLQIC&pg=PA63&dq=picus+Martius+Mars+%22green+woodpecker%22&hl=en&ei=ifEITcboAYiWnAfq-KzaDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=picus%20Martius%20Mars%20%22green%20woodpecker%22&f=false online.]</ref>
The woodpecker was revered by the [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Latin peoples]], who abstained from eating its flesh.<ref>[[Plutarch]], ''Roman Questions'' 21. [[Athenaeus]] lists the woodpecker among delicacies on Greek tables (''Deipnosophistae'' 9.369).</ref> It was one of the most important birds in Roman and Italic [[augur]]y, the practice of reading the will of the gods through watching the sky for signs.<ref>[[Plautus]], ''Asinaria'' 259–261; [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Natural History'' 10.18. Named also in the [[Iguvine Tables]] (6a, 1–7), as [[Umbrian language|Umbrian]] ''peiqu''; Schilling, "Roman Divination," in ''Roman and European Mythologies'' (University of Chicago Press, 1992), pp. 96–97 and 105, note 7.</ref> The mythological figure named [[Picus]] had powers of augury that he retained when he was transformed into a woodpecker; in one tradition, Picus was the son of Mars.<ref>[[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]] 1.31; Peter F. Dorcey, ''The Cult of Silvanus: A Study in Roman Folk Religion'' (Brill, 1992), p. 33.</ref> The [[Umbrian language|Umbrian]] [[cognate]] ''peiqu'' also means "woodpecker," and the Italic [[Picentes|Picenes]] were supposed to have derived their name from the ''picus'' who served as their guide animal during a ritual migration ''([[ver sacrum]])'' undertaken as a rite of Mars.<ref>John Greppin, entry on "woodpecker," ''Encyclopedia of Indo-European Culture'' (Fitzroy Dearborn, 1997), p. 648.</ref> In the territory of the [[Aequi]], another Italic people, Mars had an [[oracle]] of great antiquity where the prophecies were supposed to be spoken by a woodpecker perched on a wooden column.<ref>[[Dionysius Halicarnassus]], ''Roman Antiquities'' I.14.5, as noted by Mary Emma Armstrong, ''The Significance of Certain Colors in Roman Ritual'' (George Banta Publishing, 1917), p. 6.</ref>
Mars' association with the wolf is familiar from what may be the most famous of [[Roman mythology|Roman myths]], the story of how a [[She-wolf (Roman mythology)|she-wolf]] ''(lupa)'' suckled his infant sons when they were [[Infanticide#Greece and Rome|exposed]] by order of [[Amulius|King Amulius]], who feared them because he had [[usurper|usurped]] the throne from their grandfather, [[Numitor]].<ref>The myth of the she-wolf, and the birth of the twins with Mars as their father, is a long and complex tradition that weaves together multiple stories about the founding of Rome. See [[T.P. Wiseman]], ''Remus: A Roman Myth'' (Cambridge University Press, 1995), p. xiii, 73ff. ''et passim.''</ref> The woodpecker also brought nourishment to the twins.<ref>Plutarch, ''Life of Romulus'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Romulus*.html 4.]</ref>
The wolf appears elsewhere in Roman art and literature in masculine form as the animal of Mars. A statue group that stood along the [[Appian Way]] showed Mars in the company of wolves.<ref>[[Livy]] 22.1.12, as cited by Wiseman, ''Remus'', p. 189, note 6, and Armstrong, ''The Significance of Certain Colors'', p. 6.</ref> At the [[Battle of Sentinum]] in 295 BC, the appearance of the wolf of Mars ''(Martius lupus)'' was a sign that Roman victory was to come.<ref>[[Livy]], ''[[Ab Urbe Condita Libri (Livy)|Ab Urbe Condita]]'' 10.27.</ref>
In [[Gallo-Roman culture|Roman Gaul]], the goose was associated with the [[Mars (mythology)#Provincial epithets|Celtic forms of Mars]], and archaeologists have found geese buried alongside warriors in graves. The goose was considered a bellicose animal because it is easily provoked to aggression.<ref>Miranda Green, ''Animals in Celtic Life and Myth'' (Routledge, 1992), p. 126.</ref>
===Sacrificial animals=== [[File:Suovetaurilia.jpg|thumb|left|The procession of the ''[[suovetaurilia]]'', a sacrifice of a pig, ram, and bull, led by a priest with his head [[capite velato|ritually covered]]]] [[Religion in ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] and Roman religion distinguished between animals that were sacred to a deity and those that were prescribed as the correct [[animal sacrifice|sacrificial offerings]] for the god. Wild animals might be viewed as already belonging to the god to whom they were sacred, or at least not owned by human beings and therefore not [[Do ut des|theirs to give]]. Since sacrificial meat was eaten at a banquet after the gods received their portion – mainly the entrails ''([[exta]])'' – it follows that the animals sacrificed were most often, though not always, domestic animals normally part of the Roman diet.<ref>Nicole Belayche, "Religious Actors in Daily Life: Practices and Related Beliefs," in ''A Companion to Roman Religion'' (Blackwell, 2007), p. 283; C. Bennett Pascal, "October Horse," ''Harvard Studies in Classical Philology'' 85 (1981), pp. 268, 277.</ref> Gods often received castrated male animals as sacrifices, and the goddesses female [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#victima|victims]]; Mars, however, regularly received intact males.<ref>As did Neptune, Janus and the [[Genius (mythology)|Genius]]; [[John Scheid]], "Sacrifices for Gods and Ancestors," in ''A Companion to Roman Religion'' (Blackwell, 2007), p. 264.</ref> Mars did receive [[oxen]] under a few of his cult titles, such as [[Mars (mythology)#Mars Grabovius|Mars Grabovius]], but the usual offering was the bull, singly, in multiples, or in combination with other animals.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}}
The two most distinctive animal sacrifices made to Mars were the ''[[suovetaurilia]]'', a triple offering of a pig ''(sus)'', ram ''(ovis)'' and bull ''(taurus)'',<ref>[[Mary Beard (classicist)|Mary Beard]], J.A. North, and S.R.F. Price, ''Religions of Rome: A Sourcebook'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998), p. 153.</ref> and the [[October Horse]], the only [[horse sacrifice]] known to have been carried out in ancient Rome and a rare instance of a victim the Romans considered inedible.<ref>C. Bennett Pascal, "October Horse," ''Harvard Studies in Classical Philology'' 85 (1981), pp. 263, 268, 277.</ref>
==Temples and topography in Rome== The earliest center in Rome for cultivating Mars as a deity was the Altar of Mars ''([[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#ara|Ara]] Martis)'' in the [[Campus Martius]] ("Field of Mars") outside the sacred boundary of Rome ''([[pomerium]])''. The Romans thought that this altar had been established by the semi-legendary [[Numa Pompilius]], the peace-loving successor of Romulus.<ref>Lawrence Richardson, ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1992), p. 245.</ref> According to Roman tradition, the Campus Martius had been consecrated to Mars by their ancestors to serve as horse pasturage and an equestrian training ground for youths.<ref>[[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], ''Roman Antiquities'' 5.13.2</ref> During the [[Roman Republic]] (509–27 BC), the Campus was a largely open expanse. No temple was built at the altar, but from 193 BC a covered walkway connected it to the [[Porta Fontinalis]], near the office and archives of the [[Roman censor]]s. Newly elected censors placed their [[curule chair]]s by the altar, and when they had finished conducting the census, the citizens were collectively [[lustrum|purified]] with a suovetaurilia there.<ref>Livy 40.45.8, 1.44.1–2.</ref> A [[frieze]] from the so-called [[Altar of Domitius Ahenobarbus|"Altar" of Domitius Ahenobarbus]] is thought to depict the census, and may show Mars himself standing by the altar as the procession of victims advances.<ref>Katja Moede, "Reliefs, Public and Private," in ''A Companion to Roman Religion'' (Blackwell, 2007), p. 170.</ref>
[[File:Forum Augustus.JPG|thumb|Remains of the [[Temple of Mars Ultor]] in the Forum of Augustus, Rome]] The main Temple of Mars ''([[Aedes (Roman)|Aedes]] Martis)'' in the Republican period also lay outside the sacred boundary{{where|date=October 2018}} and was devoted to the god's warrior aspect.<ref>[[Vitruvius]] 1.7.1; [[Servius]], note to ''[[Aeneid]]'' 1.292; Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 244.</ref> It was built to fulfill a vow ''([[votum]])'' made by a [[Quinctia (gens)|Titus Quinctius]] in 388 BC during the [[Gallic siege of Rome]].<ref>[[Livy]] 6.5.7; Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 244.</ref> The founding day ''([[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#dies natalis|dies natalis]])'' was commemorated on June 1,<ref>Ovid, ''Fasti'' 6.191–192 and the ''[[Fasti Antiates]]'' (Degrassi 463), as cited by Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 244.</ref> and the temple is attested by several inscriptions and literary sources.<ref>''[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum|CIL]]'' 6.473, 474 = 30774, 485; ''[[Inscriptiones Latinae Selectae|ILS]]'' 3139, 3144, as cited by Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 244.</ref> The sculpture group of Mars and the wolves was displayed there.<ref>[[H.H. Scullard]], ''Festivals and Ceremonies of the Roman Republic'' (Cornell University Press, 1981), p. 127.</ref> Soldiers sometimes assembled at the temple before heading off to war, and it was the point of departure for a major parade of [[Roman cavalry]] held annually on July 15.<ref>Scullard, ''Festivals and Ceremonies,'' pp. 127, 164.</ref>
A temple to Mars in the [[Circus Flaminius]] was built around 133 BC, funded by [[Decimus Junius Brutus Callaicus]] from war booty. It housed a colossal statue of Mars and a nude Venus.<ref>Pliny, ''Natural History'' 36.26; Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 245.</ref>
The Campus Martius continued to provide venues for equestrian events such as [[chariot racing]] during the [[Roman Empire|Imperial period]], but under the first emperor [[Augustus]] it underwent a major program of urban renewal, marked by monumental architecture. The Altar of Augustan Peace ''([[Ara Pacis Augustae]])'' was located there, as was the [[Obelisk of Montecitorio]], imported from [[Roman Egypt|Egypt]] to form the pointer ''([[gnomon]])'' of the [[Solarium Augusti]], a giant [[sundial]]. With its public gardens, the Campus became one of the most attractive places in the city to visit.<ref>Paul Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos: Augustus and the Northern Campus Martius'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 2006), pp. 7–8.</ref>
Augustus chose the Campus Martius as the site of his new Temple to Mars Ultor{{clarify|date=October 2018|reason=Caption to right and pages elsewhere give location as Forum of Augustus not Campus Martius}}, a manifestation of Mars he cultivated as the avenger ''(ultor)'' of the [[assassination of Julius Caesar|murder of Julius Caesar]] and of the military disaster suffered at the [[Battle of Carrhae]]. When the legionary standards lost to the Parthians were recovered, they were housed in the new temple. The date of the temple's dedication on May 12 was aligned with the [[heliacal setting]] of the constellation [[Scorpio (constellation)|Scorpio]], the [[Astrological sign|sign]] of war.<ref>Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos,'' p. 145.</ref> The date continued to be marked with [[ludi circenses|circus games]] as late as the mid-4th century AD.<ref>Michele Renee Salzman, ''On Roman Time: The Codex Calendar of 354 and the Rhythms of Urban Life in Late Antiquity'' (University of California Press, 1990), p. 122.</ref>
A large statue of Mars was part of the short-lived [[List of Roman triumphal arches|Arch of Nero]], which was built in 62 AD but dismantled after [[Nero]]'s suicide and disgrace ''([[damnatio memoriae]])''.<ref>Richardson, ''New Topographical Dictionary,'' p. 27.</ref>
==Iconography and Symbol== {{multiple image | align = right | footer = | image1 = Othea's Epistle (Queen's Manuscript) 11.jpg | width1 = 143<!--Do not modify. This provides the same length as the other image in the frame--> | alt1 = | caption1 = Medieval representation of Mars, sitting on a rainbow with a sword and a [[sceptre]], excites men to war. | image2 = Mural warrior.jpg | width2 = 150<!--Do not modify. This provides the same length as the other image in the frame--> | alt2 = | caption2 = A nude statue of Mars<ref>Robert Schilling, "Mars," in ''Roman and European Mythologies'' (University of Chicago Press, 1992, from the French edition of 1981), p. 135 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Uf2_kHAs22sC&pg=PA135&dq=mars+intitle:mythologies&hl=en&ei=aV_pTIzqJorQngeB0-ziDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=mars%20intitle%3Amythologies&f=false online.] The figure is sometimes identified only as a warrior.</ref> in a garden setting, as depicted on a wall painting from [[Pompeii]]. | image3 = Mars Symbol.png | width3 = 140<!--Do not modify. This provides the same length as the other image in the frame--> | alt3 = | caption3 = [[Mars Symbol|The Spear of Mars]], which represents the spear and shield of Mars, is also the symbol for [[Mars|the planet Mars]] and [[male|Male gender]]. }}
In [[Roman art]], Mars is depicted as either bearded and mature, or young and clean-shaven. Even [[Nude (art)|nude]] or seminude, he often wears a helmet or carries a spear as emblems of his warrior nature. Mars was among the deities to appear on the earliest Roman coinage in the late 4th and early 3rd century BC.<ref>Jonathan Williams, "Religion and Roman Coins," in ''A Companion to Roman Religion'', p. 143.</ref>
On the Altar of Peace ''(Ara Pacis)'', built in the last years of the 1st century BC, Mars is a mature man with a "handsome, [[Classicism|classicizing]]" face, and a short curly beard and moustache. His helmet is a plumed [[neo-Attic]]-[[Attic helmet|type]]. He wears a military cloak ''([[paludamentum]])'' and a [[muscle cuirass|cuirass]] ornamented with a [[gorgoneion]]. Although the [[relief]] is somewhat damaged at this spot, he appears to hold a spear [[laurel wreath|garlanded in laurel]], symbolizing a peace that is won by military victory. The 1st-century statue of Mars found in the [[Forum of Nerva]] (pictured at top) is similar. In this guise, Mars is presented as the dignified ancestor of the Roman people. The panel of the ''Ara Pacis'' on which he appears would have faced the Campus Martius, reminding viewers that Mars was the god whose altar Numa established there, that is, the god of Rome's oldest civic and military institutions.<ref>Paul Rehak and John G. Younger, ''Imperium and Cosmos: Augustus and the Northern Campus Martius'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 2006), p. 114.</ref>
Particularly in works of art influenced by [[ancient Greek art|the Greek tradition]], Mars may be portrayed in a manner that resembles Ares, youthful, beardless, and often nude.<ref>Rehak and Younger, ''Imperium and Cosmos'', p. 114.</ref> In the Renaissance, Mars' nudity was thought to represent his lack of fear in facing danger.<ref>Entry on "Mars", in ''The Classical Tradition'', p. 564, citing Sebastiano Erizzo, ''On Ancient Medallions'' (1559), p. 120.<!--although I can't find it in that source--></ref>
