{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{lead too short|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox President |name=Sani Abacha |nationality=Nigerian |image=File:Sani Abacha.jpg |caption= |order=10th [[Nigerian military juntas of 1966–79 and 1983–98|Head of State of Nigeria]] |term_start=17 November 1993 |term_end=8 June 1998 |predecessor=[[Ernest Shonekan]] |successor=[[Abdulsalami Abubakar]] |office2 = [[Chief of the Defence Staff (Nigeria)|Chief of Defence Staff]] |term_start2 = August 1990 |term_end2 = November 1993 |predecessor2 = [[Domkat Bali]] |successor2 = [[Oladipo Diya]] |office3 = [[Chief of Army Staff (Nigeria)|Chief of Army Staff]] |term_start3 = August 1985 |term_end3 = August 1990 |predecessor3 = [[Ibrahim Babangida]] |successor3 = [[Salihu Ibrahim]] |birth_date={{birth date|1943|9|20|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Kano]], [[Northern Region, Nigeria|Northern Region]], [[British Nigeria]]
(now [[Kano]], [[Kano State]], [[Nigeria]]) |death_date={{death date and age|1998|6|8|1943|9|20|df=y}} |death_place=[[Abuja]], [[FCT, Nigeria|FCT]], Nigeria |spouse= [[Maryam Abacha]] |party=none (military) |vicepresident= |religion=[[Islam]] |signature=Signature of Sani Abacha.svg | allegiance = | branch =[[File:Flag of the Nigerian Army Headquarters.svg|21px]] [[Nigerian Army]] | serviceyears = 1963–1998 | rank = [[General]] | unit = | commands = | battles = | awards = }} '''Sani Abacha''' ({{pronunciation|En-us-Sani Abacha from Nigeria pronunciation (Voice of America).ogg}}; 20 September 1943 – 8 June 1998) was a [[Nigerian Army]] officer and politician who served as the [[List of heads of state of Nigeria|''de facto'' President]] of [[Nigeria]] from 1993 to 1998.Paden, John N. (2005) ''Muslim Civic Cultures and Conflict Resolution'', [[Brookings Institution]] Press. p. 240. {{ISBN|0-8157-6817-6}}. ==Early life and education== A [[Kanuri people|Kanuri]] from [[Borno State|Borno]], Abacha was born and brought up in [[Kano, Nigeria]]. He attended the [[Nigerian Defence Academy|Nigerian Military Training College]] and [[Mons Officer Cadet School]] before being commissioned as a 2nd lieutenant in 1963.{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.saniabacha.com/index1.php?getpage=biography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115132729/http://www.saniabacha.com/index1.php?getpage=biography|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 November 2012|publisher=Sani Abacha|accessdate=7 May 2012}} ==Military career== Abacha was [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] in 1963 after he had attended [[Mons Officer Cadet School]] in [[Aldershot]], [[England]]. Before then, he had attended the [[Nigerian Military Training College]] in [[Kaduna]].{{cn|date=November 2018}} ===Participation in coups=== Abacha's military career is distinguished by a string of successful coups. He is by some records the most successful coup plotter in the history of Nigeria's military. Abacha, then a 2nd Lieutenant with the 3rd Battalion in Kaduna, took part in the [[1966 Nigerian counter-coup|July 1966 Nigerian counter-coup]] from the conceptual stage.{{cite book|last1=Siollun|first1=Max|title=Oil, Politics and Violence: Nigeria's Military Coup Culture (1966–1976)|publisher=Algora|isbn=9780875867090|page=97}} He may have been a participant in the Lagos or Abeokuta phases of the [[1966 Nigerian coup d'état|coup the previous January]] as well.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} He was also a prominent figure in the [[1983 Nigerian coup d'état]] which brought General [[Muhammadu Buhari]] to power in 1983, and the August 1985 coup which removed Buhari from power.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} When General [[Ibrahim Babangida]] was named President and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Federal Republic of [[Nigeria]] in 1985, Abacha was named Chief of Army Staff. He was appointed [[Defence Minister of Nigeria|Minister of Defence]] in 1990.Oyewole, A. (1987) ''Historical Dictionary of Nigeria'', Scarecrow Press. p. 385. {{ISBN|0-8108-1787-X}}.{{cite web|url=http://search.eb.com/eb/article-9389478|title=Encyclopedia – Britannica Online Encyclopedia|work=eb.com}} In 1993, Abacha became the first Nigerian soldier to attain the rank of a full General without skipping a single rank.{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==Seizure of power== On 17 November 1993, Abacha overthrew the short-lived transitional government of Chief [[Ernest Shonekan]]. In September 1994, he issued a decree that placed his government above the jurisdiction of the courts, effectively giving him absolute power. Another decree gave him the right to detain anyone for up to three months without trial.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/07/world/nigerian-military-ruler-assumes-absolute-power.html|title=Nigerian Military Ruler Assumes Absolute Power|date=7 September 1994|work=AP|via=The New York Times}} ==Presidency== The Abacha administration became the first to record unprecedented economic achievements:{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/156004-why-we-honoured-abacha-nigerian-government.html|title=Why we honoured Abacha – Nigerian government – Premium Times Nigeria|work=Premium Times Nigeria}} he oversaw an increase in the country's foreign exchange reserves from $494 million in 1993 to $9.6 billion by the middle of 1997, reduced the external debt of Nigeria from $36 billion in 1993 to $27 billion by 1997, brought all the controversial privatization programs of the Babangida administration to halt, reduced an inflation rate of 54% inherited from Ibrahim Badamasi Babangida to 8.5% between 1993 and 1998, all while the nation's primary commodity, oil was at an average of $15 per barrel. ===Human rights abuses=== Abacha's government was accused of [[human rights]] abuses, especially after the hanging of [[Ogoni]] activist [[Ken Saro-Wiwa]]{{cite book|last1=Arnold|first1=Guy|title=Africa: A Modern History|date=2005|publisher=Atlantic Books|location=London|isbn=9781843541769|page=789}} by the [[Oputa Commission]] (only one of several executions of Ogoni activists opposed to the exploitation of Nigerian resources by the [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[petroleum]] company, [[Royal Dutch Shell]] Group); [[Moshood Abiola]] and [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] were jailed for treason, and [[Wole Soyinka]] charged in absentia with treason. His regime suffered opposition externally by pro-democracy activists. He however supported the [[Economic Community of West African States]] and sent Nigerian troops to [[Liberia]] and [[Sierra Leone]] to help restore democracy to those countries. Despite being repeatedly condemned by the [[US State Department]],{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/11/09/braun|title=Return of the ugly American|work=salon.com}} Abacha did have a few ties to American politics. In 1997, Senator [[James Inhofe]] ([[US Republican Party|R]]-[[Oklahoma]]) travelled to Nigeria to meet with Abacha as a representative of the "[[The Family (Christian political organization)|Family]]", a group of [[Christian evangelism|evangelical Christian]] politicians and civic leaders. Abacha and the Family had a business and political relationship from that point until his death.{{cite web|url=http://motherjones.com/politics/2010/11/doug-coe-inhofe-siljander-c-street|title=Junkets for Jesus|work=Mother Jones}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=121755993|title=A Different Perspective On 'The Family' And Uganda|date=22 December 2009|work=NPR.org}} Abacha also developed ties with other American political figures such as Senator [[Carol Moseley Braun]], Rev. [[Jesse Jackson]] and Minister [[Louis Farrakhan]]. Several African American political leaders visited Nigeria during his reign and Farrakhan supported his administration. ===Corruption allegations=== During Abacha's regime, he and his family reportedly stole a total of [[£]]5 billion from the country's coffers.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/19/world/late-nigerian-dictator-looted-nearly-500-million-swiss-say.html | work=The New York Times | title=Late Nigerian Dictator Looted Nearly $500 Million, Swiss Say | date=19 August 2004 | accessdate=9 April 2010}} In 2004, Abacha was listed as the fourth most corrupt leader in history.{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/content/download/4459/26786/file/Introduction_to_political_corruption.pdf|format=PDF|title=Introduction to Political Corruption|page=13|location=London|date=25 March 2004|website=transparency.org}} During a service marking the 10th anniversary of the death of the dictator, several former Nigerian heads of state, including [[Muhammadu Buhari|Gen. Muhammadu Buhari]], refuted claims that Abacha looted the country, claiming such accusations are "baseless".{{cite web |url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=31 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919105217/http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php |archivedate=19 September 2010 |df= }}? id=113628{{cite web|url=http://www.guardiannewsngr.com/news/article03//indexn2_html?pdate=090608&ptitle=Abacha%20served%20Nigeria%20well,%20say%20Buhari,%20Abdulsalami|title=TV and Internet Bundles - American Main Street|publisher=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.transparency.org/publications/gcr/download_gcr/download_gcr_2004 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=24 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070922043005/http://www.transparency.org/publications/gcr/download_gcr/download_gcr_2004 |archivedate=22 September 2007 |df= }} Abacha's national security adviser, Alhaji [[Ismaila Gwarzo]], played a central role in the looting and transfer of money to overseas accounts.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/26/news/26iht-swiss.2.t_3.html |title=Swiss Freeze A Dictator's Giant Cache |author=Elizabeth Olson |date=26 January 2000 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=24 June 2011}} His son [[Mohammed Abacha]] and best friend Alh. Mohammed M. Sada were also involved. A preliminary report published by the [[Abdulsalam Abubakar]] transitional government in November 1998 described the process. Sani Abacha told Ismaila Gwarzo to provide fake funding requests, which Abacha approved. The funds were usually sent in cash or travellers' cheques by the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]] to Gwarzo, who took them to Abacha's house. Mohammed Sada then arranged to launder the money to offshore accounts. But several calls for the prosecution of MM.Sada were turned down by the Olusegun Obasanjo presidency even after being indicted by the Justice Oputa lead Human Rights Violation Investigation Commission (popularly known as Oputa Panel).{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Twdt0VF-ML8C&pg=PA44 |title=Recovering stolen assets |first=Mark |last=Pieth |pages=43–44 |publisher=Peter Lang |year=2008 |ISBN=3-03911-583-9}} An estimated $1.4 billion in cash was delivered in this way.{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RGvSopqOnx0C&pg=PA178 |title=Growing apart: oil, politics, and economic change in Indonesia and Nigeria |first=Peter |last=Lewis |page=178 |publisher=University of Michigan Press |year=2007 |ISBN=0-472-06980-2}} In March 2014, the United States Department of Justice revealed that it had frozen more than $458 million believed to have been illegally obtained by Abacha and other corrupt officials.{{cite web|last=Reuters|title=US freezes $458m hidden by Nigerian ex-leader|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/03/us-freezes-458m-hidden-nigerian-ex-leader-20143664513203928.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=6 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/washingtondc/press-releases/2014/u.s.-forfeits-more-than-480-million-stolen-by-former-nigerian-dictator-in-largest-forfeiture-ever-obtained-through-a-kleptocracy-action|title=FBI — U.S. Forfeits More Than $480 Million Stolen by Former Nigerian Dictator in Largest Forfeiture Ever Obtained Through a Kleptocracy Action|work=FBI}} ==Death== Early in 1998, Abacha announced that elections would be held in August of the same year, with a view toward handing power to a civilian government on 1 October. It soon became apparent, though, that Abacha had no intention of permitting an honest election; by April he had strong-armed the country's five parties into endorsing him as the sole presidential candidate.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/10/world/new-nigeria-chief-pledges-a-return-to-civilian-rule.html|title=NEW NIGERIA CHIEF PLEDGES A RETURN TO CIVILIAN RULE|date=10 June 1998|work=The New York Times}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/109265.stm|title=BBC News – Nigeria – Abacha dies at 54|work=bbc.co.uk}} Abacha died in June 1998 while at the presidential villa in Abuja. He was buried on the same day, according to [[Muslim]] tradition, without an [[autopsy]]. This fueled speculation that he may have been executed extrajudicially by way of being poisoned by political rivals via prostitutes.{{cite web|title=General Sani Abacha Profile|url=http://www.africa-confidential.com/whos-who-profile/id/2651/|publisher=Africa Confidential|accessdate=19 June 2012}} The government identified the cause of death as a sudden [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/11/world/us-aides-say-nigeria-leader-might-have-been-poisoned.html?scp=8&sq=abacha&st=cse | work=The New York Times | title=U.S. Aides Say Nigeria Leader Might Have Been Poisoned | first=Tim | last=Weiner | date=11 July 1998 | accessdate=9 April 2010}} It is reported that he was in the company of two Indian prostitutes{{cite web | author=Malhotra, Jyoti | work=The Indian Express | title=Did Indian girls see Nigerian dictator die? | url=http://expressindia.indianexpress.com/news/ie/daily/19980821/23350964.html | accessdate=20 April 2013}} imported from [[Dubai]]. It is thought that the prostitutes laced his drink with a poisonous substance, making Abacha feel unwell around 4:30am. He retired to his bed and was dead by 6:15am.{{cite news| url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/nvnews/37233/1/general-sani-abacha-adapted-from-naiwu-osahons-boo.html | work=The Nigerian Voice | title=GENERAL SANI ABACHA (Adapted from Naiwu Osahon's book, The Viper's Den) | first=Naiwu | last=Osahon | date=28 October 2010 | accessdate=2 December 2010}} After Abacha's death, Maj. Gen. [[Abdulsalami Abubakar]], Nigeria's [[Chief of the Defence Staff (Nigeria)|Chief of Defence Staff]], was sworn in as the country's head of state. Abubakar had never before held public office and was quick to announce a transition to democracy, which led to the election of President [[Olusegun Obasanjo]]. Abacha was married to [[Maryam Abacha]] and had seven sons and three daughters.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/resources/newsmakers/world/africa/abacha.html |title="Newsmaker Profiles: Sani Abacha Nigerian President" |accessdate=26 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040408102654/http://www.cnn.com/resources/newsmakers/world/africa/abacha.html |archivedate=8 April 2004 |df= }}, ''[[CNN]]''. He left fifteen grandchildren: eight girls and seven boys. ==Legacy== Abacha's legacy is mixed. His administration oversaw [[Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group|ECOMOG]] military successes in West Africa that raised Nigeria's military profile.{{cite web|last1=Kirk-Greene|first1=Anthony|title=Obituary: General Sani Abacha|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-general-sani-abacha-1163944.html|website=The Independent (UK)|accessdate=23 August 2015}} In February 2014, during Nigeria's centenary celebrations, the Nigerian government honoured Abacha for his contributions to the country's development{{cite web|last1=Usman|first1=Talatu|title=Premium times|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/156004-why-we-honoured-abacha-nigerian-government.html|website=premiumtimesng.com|accessdate=20 June 2014}} though [[Nobel Laureate]] [[Wole Soyinka]] who was similarly honored by the administration of President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] criticized the honor bestowed on Abacha by rejecting the honor, noting it as the 'canonization of terror'.{{cite web|last1=Okpi|first1=Allwell|title=Sharing centenary award with Abacha, an insult|url=http://www.punchng.com/news/sharing-centenary-award-with-abacha-an-insult-soyinka/|website=The Punch (Nigeria)|accessdate=23 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302111720/http://www.punchng.com/news/sharing-centenary-award-with-abacha-an-insult-soyinka/|archivedate=2 March 2014|df=}} Soyinka further noted that by honouring Abacha, the government of Goodluck Jonathan had gathered "a century’s accumulated degeneracy in one preeminent symbol, then place[d] it on a podium for the nation to admire, emulate and even – worship". Abacha was largely unpopular in southern Nigeria because of his administration's human rights abuses, execution of [[Ken Saro Wiwa]], resulting in Nigeria attaining a pariah status internationally.{{cite web|title=Commonwealth Suspends Nigeria Over Executions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world/commonwealth-suspends-nigeria-over-executions.html|website=New York Times|accessdate=23 August 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Falola & Heaton|title=A History of Nigeria|publisher=Cambridge University Press, 2008|isbn=9781139472036|page=xix|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XygZjbNRap0C&pg=PR19&lpg=PR19&dq=nigeria+as+a+pariah+state+abacha&source=bl&ots=ETDHqMf0QM&sig=4DJTvfSgBx78AW0lsWzeFXv0CJc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAWoVChMIiuLBhai_xwIVScyACh34Sw0f#v=onepage&q=nigeria%20as%20a%20pariah%20state%20abacha&f=false|accessdate=23 August 2015}} ===False representation of name=== The names of Abacha, his wife [[Maryam Abacha|Maryam]], and son [[Mohammed Abacha|Mohammed]] are often used in [[advance fee fraud]] (419) scams; he is identified in scam letters as the source for money that does not exist.Zuckoff, Mitchell. "The Perfect Mark." ''[[The New Yorker]]''. [http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/05/15/060515fa_fact?currentPage=3], page 3.[http://server-wg.de:8080/nigeria/inhalt_a_z.html ''Who wants to be a millionaire?''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615044858/http://server-wg.de:8080/nigeria/inhalt_a_z.html |date=15 June 2006 }} – An online collection of Nigerian scam mails ===Recovery of stolen funds=== After Abacha's death, the Obasanjo government implicated Abacha and his family in a wholesale looting of Nigeria's coffers. The late dictator's son, [[Mohammed Abacha]], continues to maintain that all the assets in question were legitimately acquired.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/21/weekinreview/ideas-trends-a-nigerian-miracle.html | work=The New York Times | title=Ideas & Trends; A Nigerian Miracle | first=Floyd | last=Norris | date=21 April 2002 | accessdate=9 April 2010}}Easterly, William. (2002) ''The Elusive Quest for Growth'', MIT Press. p. 245. {{ISBN|0-262-55042-3}}. In 2002, Abacha's family purportedly agreed to return $1.2 billion that was taken from the central bank.The Worldwatch Institute. (2003) ''Vital Signs 2003'', The Worldwatch Institute. p. 115. {{ISBN|0-393-32440-0}}. ===U.S. forfeiture of Abacha for $480 million=== On 7 August 2014, the [[United States Department of Justice]] (DOJ) announced the largest forfeiture in the DOJ's history: the return of $480 million to the Nigerian government.{{cite web|title=U.S. Forfeits Over $480 Million Stolen by Former Nigerian Dictator in Largest Forfeiture Ever Obtained Through a Kleptocracy Action|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/us-forfeits-over-480-million-stolen-former-nigerian-dictator-largest-forfeiture-ever-obtained|website=The United States Department of Justice|accessdate=23 August 2015}} Assistant Attorney General Caldwell noted that "rather than serve his country, General Abacha used his public office in Nigeria to loot millions of dollars, engaging in brazen acts of kleptocracy". “With this judgment, we have forfeited $480 million in corruption proceeds that can be used for the benefit of the Nigerian people. Through the [[Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Initiative]], the Department of Justice’s Criminal Division denies kleptocrats like Abacha the fruits of their crimes, and protects the U.S. financial system from money laundering. In coordination with our partners in Jersey, France and the United Kingdom, we are helping to end this chapter of corruption and flagrant abuse of office.” According to the DOJ forfeiture, the assets returned to the Nigerian government represented proceeds of corruption during and after the military regime of General Abacha. The complaint alleges that General Abacha, his son [[Mohammed Abacha|Mohammed Sani Abacha]], their associate [[Abubakar Atiku Bagudu]] and others embezzled, misappropriated and extorted billions of dollars from the government of Nigeria and others, then laundered their criminal proceeds through U.S. financial institutions and the purchase of bonds backed by the United States. As alleged in the complaint, General Abacha and others systematically embezzled billions of dollars in public funds from the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]] under a false national security imperative. The complaint further alleged that Abacha and his conspirators withdrew the funds in cash and then moved the money overseas through U.S. financial institutions. General Abacha and his finance minister also allegedly caused the government of Nigeria to purchase Nigerian government bonds at vastly inflated prices from a company controlled by Bagudu and Mohammed Abacha, generating an illegal windfall of more than $282 million. In addition, Abacha and his associates allegedly extorted more than $11 million from a French company and its Nigerian affiliate in connection with payments on government contracts. Funds involved in each of these schemes were allegedly laundered through the United States. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Nigeria|Biography}} * {{Worldcat id|lccn-n97-13294}} * {{NYTtopic|people/a/sani_abacha}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1998/06/98/nigeria/109265.stm Abacha dies at 54], ''[[BBC News]]'', 8 June 1998 {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Ibrahim Babangida]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Nigerian Army|Chief of the Army Staff]]|years=1985–1990}} {{s-aft|after=[[Salihu Ibrahim]]}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Ernest Shonekan]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of Nigeria|Chairman of the Provisional Ruling Council of Nigeria]]|years=1993–1998}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abdulsalami Abubakar]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jerry Rawlings]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Economic Community of West African States|Chairman of the Economic Community of West African States]]|years=1996–1998}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abdulsalami Abubakar]]}} {{s-end}} {{Nigerian Heads of State}} {{Chiefs of Army Staff (COAS) Nigeria}} {{NigerianDefenceMinisters}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abacha, Sani}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kano]] [[Category:Nigerian Muslims]] [[Category:Kanuri people]] [[Category:Heads of state of Nigeria]] [[Category:Nigerian generals]] [[Category:Nigerian Army officers]] [[Category:Participants in the 1966 Nigerian counter-coup]] [[Category:Participants in the 1983 Nigerian military coup]] [[Category:Participants in the August 1985 Nigerian military coup]] [[Category:Participants of coups in Nigeria]] [[Category:Leaders who took power by coup]] [[Category:Defence ministers of Nigeria]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian politicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=September 2016}} '''Shiva Naipaul''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|aɪ|p|ɔː|l|,_|n|aɪ|ˈ|p|ɔː|l}}; 25 February 1945 – 13 August 1985), born '''Shivadhar Srinivasa Naipaul''' in [[Port of Spain]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], was a Trinidadian and British novelist and journalist.
==Biography== Shiva Naipaul was the younger brother of novelist [[V. S. Naipaul]]. He went first to [[Queen's Royal College]] and [[Saint Mary's College, Trinidad and Tobago|St Mary's College]] in Trinidad, then emigrated to Britain, having won a scholarship to study Chinese at [[University College, Oxford]]. At Oxford, he met and later married Jenny Stuart, with whom he had a son, Tarun.<ref name=Wheatcroft>Geoffrey Wheatcroft, [https://www.spectator.co.uk/2005/08/sardonic-genius/ "Sardonic Genius - Geoffrey Wheatcroft recalls his friendship with the writer Shiva Naipaul, who died 20 years ago"], ''[[The Spectator]]'', 13 August 2005.</ref>
With Jenny's support, Shiva Naipaul wrote his first novel, ''Fireflies'' (1970), which won the [[Winifred Holtby Memorial Prize]] from the Royal Society of Literature for best regional novel. It was followed by ''[[The Chip-Chip Gatherers]]'' (1973). He then decided to concentrate on [[journalism]], and wrote two non-fiction works, ''[[North of South]]'' (1978) and ''[[Black & White (book)|Black & White]]'' (1980), before returning to the novel form in the 1980s with ''[[A Hot Country]]'' (1983), a departure from his two earlier comic novels set in Trinidad, as well as a collection of fiction and non-fiction, ''[[Beyond the Dragon's Mouth: Stories and Pieces]]'' (1984).<ref name=Wheatcroft />
On the morning of 13 August 1985, at the age of 40, Naipaul had a fatal [[heart attack]] while working at his desk.<ref name=Wheatcroft />
==Legacy and posthumous reputation== ''[[The Spectator]]'' magazine, for which his wife Jenny had worked as a secretary, and which had published many of his articles, established the Shiva Naipaul Memorial Prize.<ref>[http://www.spectator.co.uk/the-magazine/features/29375/part_8/the-visit.thtml "The visit"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''The Spectator''.<!-- Bot generated title --></ref>
In [[Paul Theroux]]'s ''Sir Vidia's Shadow'', a memoir of Shiva's elder brother, V. S. Naipaul, Theroux described Shiva as a "sot", shrunken by the towering figure of his successful brother, with a penchant for drunken partying and a need to have his meals made for him. Theroux also took issue with Naipaul's skills as a writer, particularly as a [[travel literature|travel writer]].
''Sir Vidia's Shadow'' has come under attack for what are described as inaccuracies,<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2008/03/23/sv_naipaul.xml&page=3 Patrick French's biography of VS Naipaul: Naipaul's friendship with Paul Theroux], ''The Daily Telegraph''.<!-- Bot generated title --></ref> and the novelist [[Martin Amis]] wrote that "Shiva Naipaul was one of those people who caused your heart to lift when he entered the room ... in losing him, we have lost thirty years of untranscribed, unvarnished genius".<ref>Martin Amis, ''New Statesman'', April 1973, "Black and White" by Shiva Naipaul, reprinted in ''The War Against Cliché: Essays and Reviews, 1971–2000''.</ref><ref>Matthew Craft, [http://articles.courant.com/2001-11-16/features/0111161412_1_sir-kingsley-amis-cliches-levine "A Critical Take On Cliche"], ''Hartford Courant'', 16 November 2001.</ref>
An ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' [[Documentary film|documentary]] on his brother V. S. Naipaul reproduced footage of Shiva from an earlier documentary from the early 1980s, in which Shiva returned to Trinidad to see his mother.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b009s80n|title=''Arena: The Strange Luck of V.S. Naipaul''|publisher= BBC iPlayer.<!-- Bot generated title -->|format=[[Adobe Flash]]|subscription=yes}}{{expired link|date=September 2016}}</ref>
==Works== *''Fireflies'' (1970) *''[[The Chip-Chip Gatherers]]'' (1973) *''[[North of South]]'' (1978) *''[[Black & White (book)|Black & White]]'' (1980), published in the U.S. as ''Journey to Nowhere'' *''[[A Hot Country]]'' (1983), published in the U.S. as ''Love and Death in a Hot Country'' *''[[Beyond the Dragon's Mouth: Stories and Pieces]]'' (1984) *''[[An Unfinished Journey]]'' (1986). *''A Man of Mystery and Other Stories'' (1995), a selection of stories taken from ''Beyond the Dragon's Mouth''.
==See also== * [[Capildeo family]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/n/shiva-naipaul/ Bibliography] at fanstasticfiction.co.uk

revision.text: [[File:Solar designer.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Solar Designer at [[Positive Hack Days|PHDays]] 2012]] '''Alexander Peslyak''' ('''Александр Песляк''') (born 1977), better known as '''Solar Designer''', is a security specialist from Russia. He is best known for his publications on exploitation techniques, including the [[return-to-libc attack]] and the first [[Buffer overflow#Heap-based exploitation|generic heap-based buffer overflow]] exploitation technique,{{cite web|url=http://www.openwall.com/advisories/OW-002-netscape-jpeg/|accessdate=2009-08-04|title=JPEG COM Marker Processing Vulnerability in Netscape Browsers}} as well as [[computer security]] protection techniques such as [[privilege separation]] for [[daemon (computer software)|daemon]] processes. Peslyak is the author of the widely popular{{cite web|url=http://sectools.org/crackers.html|accessdate=2009-08-04|title=Top 10 Password Crackers| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090830214130/http://sectools.org/crackers.html| archivedate= 30 August 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[password cracking]] tool [[John the Ripper]]. His code has also been used in various third-party operating systems, such as [[OpenBSD]] and [[Debian]]. == Work == Peslyak has been the founder and leader of the [[Openwall Project]] since 1999. He is the founder of Openwall, Inc. and has been the CTO since 2003. He served as an advisory board member at the Open Source Computer Emergency Response Team (oCERT) from 2008 until oCERT's conclusion in August 2017{{cite web|url=https://ocert.org/|title=Open Source Computer Security Incident Response Team|accessdate=25 October 2018}}. He also co-founded oss-security.{{cite web|url=http://openwall.info/wiki/people/solar/bio|accessdate=2009-08-04|title=Alexander Peslyak's Bio on openwall.info| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090628151117/http://openwall.info/wiki/people/solar/bio| archivedate= 28 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} He has spoken at many international conferences, including [[FOSDEM]] and CanSecWest. He wrote the foreword to [[Michał Zalewski|Michał Zalewski's]] 2005 book ''Silence on the Wire''.{{cite web|url=http://lcamtuf.coredump.cx/silence.shtml|title=Silence on the Wire|year=2005|author=Michał Zalewski|authorlink=Michał Zalewski|publisher=No Starch Press|isbn=1593270461|accessdate=2015-03-21}} Alexander received the 2009 "Lifetime Achievement Award"{{cite web|url=http://pwnies.com/archive/2009/winners/|accessdate=2010-12-17|title=2009 Pwnie award}} during the annual [[Pwnie award|Pwnie Award]] at the [[Black Hat Briefings|Black Hat Security Conference]]. In 2015 [[Qualys]] acknowledged his help with the disclosure of a [[GNU C Library]] gethostbyname function buffer overflow ([[Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures|CVE]]-2015-0235).{{cite web|url=http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2015/Jan/111|title=CVE-2015-0235 - GHOST: glibc gethostbyname buffer overflow|author=[[Qualys]]|publisher=Seclists.org|date=2015-01-27|accessdate=2015-03-21}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.openwall.com/ Openwall Project home page] * [http://openwall.info/wiki/people/solar Solar Designer's pseudo homepage] * http://phrack.org/issues/69/2.html#article [[Category:People associated with computer security]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

[[Warner Music]] Malaysia (2011–2014) | associated_acts = [[Adira]], Akim Ahmad, [[KRU]] }} }} '''Ummu Syaikhah Stacy binti Anam''' (born 18 August 1990), known professionally as '''Stacy''', is a Malaysian singer, songwriter who rose to fame after winning the [[Akademi Fantasia, Season 6|sixth season]] of ''[[Akademi Fantasia]]'', receiving 43% of over 3.8 million votes.{{cite web|url=http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=/2008/5/25/HIBURAN/m_Aduh/Stacy_juara_af6|title=Stacy juara AF6|author=Zanariah Abd Mutalib|language=Malay|publisher=mStar|date=25 May 2008|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318053844/http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=%2F2008%2F5%2F25%2FHIBURAN%2Fm_Aduh%2FStacy_juara_af6|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Her debut album, ''[[Aku Stacy (album)|Aku Stacy]]'', was released on 9 March 2009. She's also known as ''' Malaysia's Dancing Queen,'''{{cite web|url=http://worldstage.mtvasia.com/news/7-stacy-music-videos-to-watch/|title=7 Stacy Music Videos to Watch|publisher=World Stage: [[MTV Southeast Asia]]|date=7 September 2015|accessdate=16 March 2017}} and has been cited as "'''Ratu Pop'''".{{cite web|url=http://youth.bernama.com/v2/news.php?id=1400865|title=Stacy Kembali Beraksi Dengan 'Cakap Ke Tangan'|author=Muhammad Zaini Mohd Zain|language=Malay|publisher=Lifestyle & Youth Bernama|accessdate=16 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171017041855/http://youth.bernama.com/v2/news.php?id=1400865|archivedate=17 October 2017|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://cosmopolitan.my/tiada-siapa-boleh-merampas-gelaran-ratu-pop-daripada-stacy/|title=Tiada Siapa Boleh Merampas Gelaran Ratu Pop Daripada Stacy!|author=Curly Jow|language=Malay|publisher=Cosmopolitan.my|accessdate=22 October 2018}} == Musical career == === ''Akademi Fantasia'' === {{main|Akademi Fantasia, Season 6}} Stacy competed against thirteen other contestants to win Season 6 of ''Akademi Fantasia''. The judging panel often harbours her performances with praises every week for being consistent, which implied her as the front-runner of the season. Ramli M.S., the academy principal of AF6 complimented Stacy as a loyal student who is very serious in learning something new. According to him, Stacy is always focus during each lesson and applied all the lessons that she learned during her performances on stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=/2008/3/31/HIBURAN/m_Aduh/AF6_Stacy_paling_menyerlah|title=AF6: Stacy paling menyerlah|author=Siti Azira Abd Aziz|language=Malay|publisher=mStar|date=31 March 2008|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318054154/http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=%2F2008%2F3%2F31%2FHIBURAN%2Fm_Aduh%2FAF6_Stacy_paling_menyerlah|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Throughout the competition, Stacy remained at top three when the voting session was closed at the end of every concert, with four collective highest votes. Before the finale concert, three out of four media reporters predicted her to be the winner of the show. At the end of the finale, the prediction came true when she was crowned as the sixth winner of the show, beating four other students, with a vote of 43%. {| class="wikitable collapsible autocollapse" style="width:90%; margin:1em auto 1em auto;" |- ! colspan="6" style="background:#BFBFBF;"| ''Akademi Fantasia'' season 6 performances and results |- |- ! Week ! Instructed Songs ! Original Artist ! Result # |- | Week 1 | "[[No One (Alicia Keys song)|No One]]" |align="center"|[[Alicia Keys]] |align="center"|2 |- | Week 2 | "Rela" |align="center"|Tila |align="center"|1 |- | Week 3 | "Pelesit Kota" |align="center"|[[Kumpulan Search]] |align="center"|1 |- | Week 4 | "[[Cinta Terhalang|Cinta Khayalan]]" |align="center"|Bob AF2/Stacy |align="center"|2 |- | Week 5 | "Makhluk Tuhan Paling Sexy" |align="center"|[[Mulan Jameela]] |align="center"|2 |- | Week 6 | "[[Don't Speak]]" |align="center"|[[No Doubt]] |align="center"|1 |- | Week 7 | "Hati" |align="center"|[[Siti Nurhaliza]] |align="center"|1 |- | Week 8 | "Gembira Hidup Ini" |align="center"|Farah AF2 |align="center"|3 |- | Week 9 | "[[Beat It]]"

Stacy |align="center"|Winner |- |} === 2008–2010: ''Aku Stacy'' === Stacy's coronation song "[[Aku Stacy (song)|Aku Stacy]]" was released immediately after her win and it became a huge success. The song quickly became her first number one single in Carta [[Era FM|Era]] for two weeks, as well as topping Carta 30 Era at number one. It stayed in the chart for 22 weeks, making its own history as one of the songs that stayed in the chart for a long period of time. The single also entered Muzik FM chart at number 9. The song slowly climbed to top the chart at No. 1, making it as Stacy's first No. 1 single in the chart. In Hot FM 30, the song only managed to peak at number 14 before finally dropping out from the chart. In Muzik Muzik, it peaked at No. 3. Following the successful release of her first single, Stacy's own show "Aku Stacy" was launched in [[Astro Ria]]. The show featured her journey in the [[entertainment industry]] after her win. In the meantime, her first compilation live album, ''The Best of Stacy'' was released in September 2008 which featured all of her ten performances in Akademi Fantasia, excluding the fifth concert. The album was well-received as it sold thousand copies in the first week. In December 2008, the song "Aku Stacy" made it to the final round of [[Anugerah Juara Lagu]], an annual award show in Malaysia to honour the best Malay song every year, a rare accomplishment made by newcomers in the industry.Despite her busy schedules to be fully prepared for [[Anugerah Juara Lagu]], Stacy's second single, "[[Gagap]]", premiered in the season finale of [[:ms:Sehati Berdansa|Sehati Berdansa]]. The song is commercially successful as it becomes her second single to reach Top 5 in most charts. In Carta [[Era FM|Era]], the single has peaked at number 2 and was held off by [[Mohd Aizam Mat Saman|Adam]]'s "Benar-Benar". In Carta Hot Fm, the song debuted at number 17 and went to peak at number 5. The song also entered Carta Muzik FM at number 10, and eventually peaked at number 4. In Carta Muzik Muzik, the second peaked at number 2, being held of by Adam's "Benar-Benar". Along with Nubhan, fellow student of AF6, Stacy was listed fourth in Murai's list of "Most Outstanding Newcomers of 2008". In February 2009, Stacy was short-listed as the top 5 finalist for three major categories in [[Anugerah Bintang Popular]], namely Most Popular Artiste, Most Popular Female New Artist, as well as Most Popular Female Singer,{{cite web|url=http://www.pressreader.com/malaysia/utusan-borneo-sarawak/20150902/282690455955245|title=Stacy bakal beraksi di MTV World Stage 2015|language=Malay|work=[[Utusan Borneo]]|publisher=[[PressReader]]|date=2 September 2015|accessdate=18 March 2017}} where she was voted as the Most Popular Female New Artist. Stacy was also given a certificate of recognition by Sabah's Ministry of Sport and Youth (KBS) for her on-going efforts to improve herself as a newcomer in entertainment industry. She was also recognised as Sabah's youth icon and idol in the entertainment industry. Her debut album, ''[[Aku Stacy (album)|Aku Stacy]]'', was released on 9 March 2009. She worked closely with notable local composers such as Ajai, Adi Mok as well as Edry [[KRU]] and Kieran Kuek. Just like the previous winners of [[Akademi Fantasia]], she gets the opportunity to launch her album in her own town which takes place in Kota Kinabalu. Stacy's third single, "[[Pakai Buang]]" was released on 9 May 2009. The song slowly climbs national charts and so far is peaking at No. 5 in Carta Muzik FM. In Carta [[:ms:Muzik Muzik|Muzik Muzik]], "Pakai Buang" debuted at number 5 and is currently peaking at No. 4. In June 2009, Stacy was nominated in Shout! Awards 2009 for the category of Popstar Award, in which she won.{{cite web|url=http://voize.my/happenings/shout-awards-winners|title=Shout! Awards Winners|publisher=Voize|date=18 July 2009|accessdate=30 July 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720201856/http://voize.my/happenings/shout-awards-winners|archivedate=20 July 2009|deadurl=yes}} She was also being nominated in two categories of 2009 [[Anugerah Planet Muzik]], which are Best Vocal Performance in a Song for New Female Artiste as well as Most Popular Malaysian Artiste which was won by [[Siti Nurhaliza]] by only 1%. Stacy was voted second. === Astro Mania! === In March 2011, Stacy participated in Astro Mania! contest where Malaysia's established singers compete amongst themselves to be crowned the Superstar. Stacy was selected by [[M. Nasir]] to join his red team. She remained at Top 5 every week in the competition until the finals. She ended up as runner-up winning [[Malaysian ringgit|RM]]250,000. === 2013: ''[[Stay-C]]'' === Her second album, entitled ''[[Stay-C]]'' was released on 9 September 2011. The album contains eight new songs, with the lead radio single, ''Kisah Dongeng''. The album is produced by [[Astro (Malaysian satellite television)|Astro]] and distributed by [[Warner Music|Warner Music Malaysia]]. On 11 November 2011, Stacy's new single "Kasanova" was officially launched with behind the scenes footage, special acoustics performances and the world premiere of ''Kasanova'' music video. "Pelangi Senja" was released as the third single from Stay-C. The song was a commercial success, peaking atop Hot.fm and [[:ms:Muzik Muzik|Muzik Muzik]] charts. The ballad showcased Stacy's versatile vocals, with critics praising her vocal performance in the song. The song was also hailed at No.2 as the most popular song in Malaysia in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribunnews.com/seleb/2012/12/12/inilah-20-lagu-terpopuler-malaysia-saat-ini|title=Inilah 20 Lagu Terpopuler Malaysia Saat Ini|language=Indonesian|work=Tribun News|publisher=TribunSeleb|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318042520/http://m.tribunnews.com/seleb/2012/12/12/inilah-20-lagu-terpopuler-malaysia-saat-ini|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} Stacy managed to get to the final of the 27th [[Anugerah Juara Lagu]]. The video was released in July 2012. === 2014–2016: [[Number 1 (Stacy album)|#1]] === The success of her final single from Stay-C, "Bosan" is proven when the song managed to compete in the grand final of AJL28 in January 2014. It was her fifth time competing in the final round of the most prestigious musical event in Malaysia. Her performance was received with mixed reviews by critics.{{cite web|url=http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/Hiburan/20140129/hi_06/AJL28-memuaskan|title=AJL28 memuaskan|author=Ifqdar Rahman|language=Malay|publisher=[[Utusan Malaysia]]|date=29 January 2014|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318025626/http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/Hiburan/20140129/hi_06/AJL28-memuaskan|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} Stacy's third album, ''[[Number 1 (Stacy album)|#1]]'' was released on 17 May 2014 at [[Zouk (club)|Zouk]] [[Kuala Lumpur|KL]]. The album contains 10 songs, including the single, "Gilalah" and the collaboration with Indonesian boyband, [[SM*SH]], "Hello". The album has 2 CDs, whereby CD2 features remix version of the songs. Besides Malaysia, the album was released in Singapore, [[Indonesia]] and [[Brunei]]. The album proved Stacy's artistry as she was involved directly in the making of the album from the beginning to the end. Stacy proved herself once again as a consistent artist when her first single "Gilalah" made it to the final of [[:ms:Anugerah Juara Lagu ke-29|AJL29]] in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.bharian.com.my/node/20385|title=Saingan sengit 12 finalis AJL 29|author=Zaidi Mohamad|language=Malay|publisher=[[Berita Harian]]|date=29 November 2014|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318034417/http://www.bharian.com.my/node/20385|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} "Gilalah" was a commercial success, having been played on the mainstream radios such as [[Era FM|ERA.fm]] and Hot.fm every so often. It was the first song where Stacy was involved in making the lyrics totally. The video of the single was directed by herself and first showed exclusively on [[:ms:MeleTOP|MeleTop]]. In September 2014, Stacy released the video of "Patah" a promotional single from the album. Despite the solid vocal performance, the song failed to crack the radio charts. Stacy made a triumphant comeback to the music and radio charts with her third single, "Not For Sale" featuring [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] famous rapper [[:ms:Altimet|Altimet]], which charted highly on most radio charts, as well as topping the Muzik-Muzik charts. "Not For Sale" also became a soundtrack for Malay popular drama "Tuan Anas Mikael". The accompanying music video was released on 4 August 2015. The song also brought Stacy to her 7th AJL appearance in January 2016. Although she was sick a day before her performance, she wowed the audiences with her vocals and moves.{{cite web|url=http://www.bharian.com.my/node/117252|title=Stacy abai kesakitan demi AJL30|author=Syarrizuan Abdul Rashid|language=Malay|publisher=Berita Harian|date=23 January 2016|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318025142/http://www.bharian.com.my/node/117252|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} It is confirmed that Stacy would release a new single entitled "Romeo" in December 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.mstar.com.my/hiburan/berita-hiburan/2015/12/01/akim-ahmad/|title=Akim Ahmad Cipta Lagu Tentang Kisah Cinta Dengan Stacy|author=Kemalia Othman|language=Malay|publisher=mStar|date=1 December 2015|accessdate=18 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318054459/http://www.mstar.com.my/hiburan/berita-hiburan/2015/12/01/akim-ahmad/|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} The single was later released on 30 January 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BBJrO05o7O4/|title=Stacy Recent Post Status|publisher=[[Instagram]]|accessdate=18 March 2017}} Her husband, Akim wrote the song for her. After her marriage with Akim, she released a song called "Bila-Bila" which discusses her love for her husband. The song was released on Team Sangat Gila Stacy channel on [[YouTube]] on 22 October 2016. Stacy later took a break from music due to pregnancy and taking care of her family. === 2017-present: Cakap Ke Tangan and ''Rhyme & Rhythm Music Entertainment (R&R)''=== After about a year hiatus, Stacy released her new dance-pop single titled "Cakap Ke Tangan" on 25 August 2017.{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/cakap-ke-tangan-single/id1272164007 |title=Cakap Ke Tangan - Single |publisher=Apple Music |page= |accessdate=18 October 2017}} The song is written by her husband, Akim Ahmad and Laq.{{cite web |url=https://www.nst.com.my/lifestyle/groove/2017/10/291731/stacy-hands-out-world-class-act-cakap-ke-tangan-mv |title=Stacy hands out world class act with Cakap Ke Tangan MV|publisher=New Straits Times |author=Aref Omar|accessdate=18 October 2017}} The official music video for the single was released on 13 October 2017 and is directed by Casper, whom she works with for "Not For Sale" video. In July 2018, Stacy announced that she is not renewing her contract with her management company, Rocketfuel Entertainment. She has been with the company since her [[Akademi Fantasia]] debut in 2008.{{cite web |url=https://www.hmetro.com.my/utama/2018/07/362087/tempuh-kehidupan-baru |title=Tempuh kehidupan baru|date=27 July 2018|publisher=Harian Metro|language=Malay |author=Sudirman Mohd Tahir|accessdate=27 July 2018}} She also announced that she has set-up her own talent management company, Rhyme & Rhythm Music Entertainment with husband, Akim. ==Discography == === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable" ! Due to her family's financial problem, she had no choice but to drop out of school at the age of 16 when she was in Secondary 4.{{cite web|url=http://intrend.astroawani.com/detail/eksklusif-tahun-pertama-ummu-syaikhah-stacy-menyambut-ramadan-sebagai-muslimah-dan-isteri-108023|title=[EKSKLUSIF] Tahun Pertama Ummu Syaikhah Stacy Menyambut Ramadan Sebagai Muslimah dan Isteri|author=Rosie Haslinda Nasir|language=Malay|publisher=[[Astro Awani]]|date=13 June 2016|accessdate=16 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318052809/http://intrend.astroawani.com/detail/eksklusif-tahun-pertama-ummu-syaikhah-stacy-menyambut-ramadan-sebagai-muslimah-dan-isteri-108023|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes}} To support her family, she became a singer in local clubs. Prior to her audition for AF6, Stacy tried out for other notable singing reality shows, such as [[One in a Million (Malaysian TV series)|One in a Million 1]], and also [[Gang Starz]] in which she teamed up with her brother, Camellus De'lleli Anam, to form a group named E-voke. However, she only made it to the semi-finals before they were booted out.{{cite web|url=http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=/2007/5/28/HIBURAN/m_Aduh/Gang_Starz_Colabr8_kecewa_keputusan_TV3|title=Gang Starz: Colabr8 kecewa keputusan TV3|author=Wahida Asrani|language=Malay|publisher=mStar|date=28 May 2007|accessdate=16 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318053252/http://www.mstar.com.my/artikel/?file=%2F2007%2F5%2F28%2FHIBURAN%2Fm_Aduh%2FGang_Starz_Colabr8_kecewa_keputusan_TV3|archivedate=18 March 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Her decision to audition for AF6 was derived from her mother's suggestion as soon as she turned 18. Stacy was also given a full scholarship to continue her studies in [[Limkokwing University Of Creative Technology]]. She studied in diploma of music and art, and began her first semester in February 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.limkokwing.net/media/news/af6_winner_stacy_receives_scholarship_to_study_at_limkokwing_music_academy/|title=AF6 winner Stacy receives scholarship to study at Limkokwing music academy|work=[[Utusan Malaysia]]|publisher=[[Limkokwing University of Creative Technology]]|date=23 July 2008|accessdate=16 March 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111072437/http://www.limkokwing.net/media/news/af6_winner_stacy_receives_scholarship_to_study_at_limkokwing_music_academy/|archivedate=11 January 2010|deadurl=yes}} Stacy was a Christian before embracing Islam in August 2015, and chose ''Ummu Syaikhah Stacy binti Anam'' as her Muslim name. Stacy married Malaysian singer-songwriter [[:ms:Afiq Hakim Ahmad|Akim Ahmad]] in [[Kota Kinabalu]], [[Sabah]] in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2016/02/05/akim-weds-stacy-and-falls-in-love-all-over-again-with-his-bride/|title=Akim weds Stacy, and falls in love all over again with his bride|author=Sandra Sokial|publisher=[[The Rakyat Post]]|date=5 February 2016|accessdate=16 March 2017}} On 17 February 2017, the couple welcomed their first child, a daughter named Eshaal.{{cite web|url=http://www.sinarharian.com.my/hiburan/stacy-selamat-bersalin-anak-perempuan-1.630360|title=Stacy selamat bersalin anak perempuan|language=Malay|publisher=Sinar Harian|date=17 February 2017|accessdate=22 October 2018}} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Television shows and appearances !
